Looks up a key in the #GHashTable, stealing the original key and the associated value and returning %TRUE if the key was found. If the key was not found, %FALSE is returned.
If found, the stolen key and value are removed from the hash table without calling the key and value destroy functions, and ownership is transferred to the caller of this method, as with g_hash_table_steal(). That is the case regardless whether @stolen_key or @stolen_value output parameters are requested.
You can pass %NULL for @lookup_key, provided the hash and equal functions of @hash_table are %NULL-safe.
The dictionary implementation optimizes for having all values identical to their keys, for example by using g_hash_table_add(). Before 2.82, when stealing both the key and the value from such a dictionary, the value was %NULL. Since 2.82, the returned value and key will be the same.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: stolen_key
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the original key

parameter.name: stolen_value
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the value associated with the key

function.return: %TRUE if the key was found in the #GHashTable

function.name: g_hash_table_thaw
function.description: This function is deprecated and will be removed in the next major release of GLib. It does nothing.

function.name: g_hash_table_unref
function.description:
Atomically decrements the reference count of @hash_table by one. If the reference count drops to 0, all keys and values will be destroyed, and all memory allocated by the hash table is released. This function is MT-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.10

function.name: g_hmac_copy
function.description:
Copies a #GHmac. If @hmac has been closed, by calling g_hmac_get_string() or g_hmac_get_digest(), the copied HMAC will be closed as well.
Since: 2.30
function.return: the copy of the passed #GHmac. Use g_hmac_unref() when finished using it.

function.name: g_hmac_get_digest
function.description:
Gets the digest from @checksum as a raw binary array and places it into @buffer. The size of the digest depends on the type of checksum.
Once this function has been called, the #GHmac is closed and can no longer be updated with g_checksum_update().
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: digest_len
parameter.parameter_description: an inout parameter. The caller initializes it to the size of @buffer. After the call it contains the length of the digest

function.name: g_hmac_get_string
function.description:
Gets the HMAC as a hexadecimal string.
Once this function has been called the #GHmac can no longer be updated with g_hmac_update().
The hexadecimal characters will be lower case.
Since: 2.30
function.return: the hexadecimal representation of the HMAC. The returned string is owned by the HMAC and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: g_hmac_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GHmac, using the digest algorithm @digest_type. If the @digest_type is not known, %NULL is returned. A #GHmac can be used to compute the HMAC of a key and an arbitrary binary blob, using different hashing algorithms.
A #GHmac works by feeding a binary blob through g_hmac_update() until the data is complete; the digest can then be extracted using g_hmac_get_string(), which will return the checksum as a hexadecimal string; or g_hmac_get_digest(), which will return a array of raw bytes. Once either g_hmac_get_string() or g_hmac_get_digest() have been called on a #GHmac, the HMAC will be closed and it won't be possible to call g_hmac_update() on it anymore.
Support for digests of type %G_CHECKSUM_SHA512 has been added in GLib 2.42. Support for %G_CHECKSUM_SHA384 was added in GLib 2.52.
Since: 2.30
function.return: the newly created #GHmac, or %NULL. Use g_hmac_unref() to free the memory allocated by it.

function.name: g_hmac_ref
function.description:
Atomically increments the reference count of @hmac by one.
This function is MT-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.30
function.return: the passed in #GHmac.

function.name: g_hmac_unref
function.description:
Atomically decrements the reference count of @hmac by one.
If the reference count drops to 0, all keys and values will be destroyed, and all memory allocated by the hash table is released. This function is MT-safe and may be called from any thread. Frees the memory allocated for @hmac.
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_hmac_update
function.description:
Feeds @data into an existing #GHmac.
The HMAC must still be open, that is g_hmac_get_string() or g_hmac_get_digest() must not have been called on @hmac.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: buffer used to compute the checksum

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: size of the buffer, or -1 if it is a nul-terminated string

function.name: g_hook_alloc
function.description: Allocates space for a #GHook and initializes it.
function.return: a new #GHook

function.name: g_hook_append
function.description: Appends a #GHook onto the end of a #GHookList.

parameter.name: hook
parameter.parameter_description: the #GHook to add to the end of @hook_list

function.name: g_hook_compare_ids
function.description: Compares the ids of two #GHook elements, returning a negative value if the second id is greater than the first.
function.return: a value <= 0 if the id of @sibling is >= the id of @new_hook

function.name: g_hook_destroy
function.description: Destroys a #GHook, given its ID.
function.return: %TRUE if the #GHook was found in the #GHookList and destroyed

function.name: g_hook_destroy_link
function.description: Removes one #GHook from a #GHookList, marking it inactive and calling g_hook_unref() on it.

function.name: g_hook_find
function.description: Finds a #GHook in a #GHookList using the given function to test for a match.

parameter.name: need_valids
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if #GHook elements which have been destroyed should be skipped

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each #GHook, which should return %TRUE when the #GHook has been found

function.return: the found #GHook or %NULL if no matching #GHook is found

function.name: g_hook_find_data
function.description: Finds a #GHook in a #GHookList with the given data.

parameter.name: need_valids
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if #GHook elements which have been destroyed should be skipped

function.return: the #GHook with the given @data or %NULL if no matching #GHook is found

function.name: g_hook_find_func
function.description: Finds a #GHook in a #GHookList with the given function.

parameter.name: need_valids
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if #GHook elements which have been destroyed should be skipped

function.return: the #GHook with the given @func or %NULL if no matching #GHook is found

function.name: g_hook_find_func_data
function.description: Finds a #GHook in a #GHookList with the given function and data.

parameter.name: need_valids
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if #GHook elements which have been destroyed should be skipped

function.return: the #GHook with the given @func and @data or %NULL if no matching #GHook is found

function.name: g_hook_first_valid
function.description: Returns the first #GHook in a #GHookList which has not been destroyed. The reference count for the #GHook is incremented, so you must call g_hook_unref() to restore it when no longer needed. (Or call g_hook_next_valid() if you are stepping through the #GHookList.)

parameter.name: may_be_in_call
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if hooks which are currently running (e.g. in another thread) are considered valid. If set to %FALSE, these are skipped

function.return: the first valid #GHook, or %NULL if none are valid

function.name: g_hook_free
function.description: Calls the #GHookList @finalize_hook function if it exists, and frees the memory allocated for the #GHook.

function.name: g_hook_get
function.description: Returns the #GHook with the given id, or %NULL if it is not found.
function.return: the #GHook with the given id, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_hook_insert_before
function.description: Inserts a #GHook into a #GHookList, before a given #GHook.

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: the #GHook to insert the new #GHook before

function.name: g_hook_insert_sorted
function.description: Inserts a #GHook into a #GHookList, sorted by the given function.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the comparison function used to sort the #GHook elements

function.name: g_hook_list_clear
function.description: Removes all the #GHook elements from a #GHookList.

function.name: g_hook_list_init
function.description: Initializes a #GHookList. This must be called before the #GHookList is used.

parameter.name: hook_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of each element in the #GHookList, typically `sizeof (GHook)`.

function.name: g_hook_list_invoke
function.description: Calls all of the #GHook functions in a #GHookList.

parameter.name: may_recurse
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if functions which are already running (e.g. in another thread) can be called. If set to %FALSE, these are skipped

function.name: g_hook_list_invoke_check
function.description: Calls all of the #GHook functions in a #GHookList. Any function which returns %FALSE is removed from the #GHookList.

parameter.name: may_recurse
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if functions which are already running (e.g. in another thread) can be called. If set to %FALSE, these are skipped

function.name: g_hook_list_marshal
function.description: Calls a function on each valid #GHook.

parameter.name: may_recurse
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if hooks which are currently running (e.g. in another thread) are considered valid. If set to %FALSE, these are skipped

parameter.name: marshaller
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each #GHook

function.name: g_hook_list_marshal_check
function.description: Calls a function on each valid #GHook and destroys it if the function returns %FALSE.

parameter.name: may_recurse
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if hooks which are currently running (e.g. in another thread) are considered valid. If set to %FALSE, these are skipped

parameter.name: marshaller
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each #GHook

function.name: g_hook_next_valid
function.description: Returns the next #GHook in a #GHookList which has not been destroyed. The reference count for the #GHook is incremented, so you must call g_hook_unref() to restore it when no longer needed. (Or continue to call g_hook_next_valid() until %NULL is returned.)

parameter.name: may_be_in_call
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if hooks which are currently running (e.g. in another thread) are considered valid. If set to %FALSE, these are skipped

function.return: the next valid #GHook, or %NULL if none are valid

function.name: g_hook_prepend
function.description: Prepends a #GHook on the start of a #GHookList.

parameter.name: hook
parameter.parameter_description: the #GHook to add to the start of @hook_list

function.name: g_hook_ref
function.description: Increments the reference count for a #GHook.

parameter.name: hook
parameter.parameter_description: the #GHook to increment the reference count of

function.return: the @hook that was passed in (since 2.6)

function.name: g_hook_unref
function.description: Decrements the reference count of a #GHook. If the reference count falls to 0, the #GHook is removed from the #GHookList and g_hook_free() is called to free it.

function.name: g_hostname_is_ascii_encoded
function.description:
Tests if @hostname contains segments with an ASCII-compatible encoding of an Internationalized Domain Name. If this returns %TRUE, you should decode the hostname with g_hostname_to_unicode() before displaying it to the user.
Note that a hostname might contain a mix of encoded and unencoded segments, and so it is possible for g_hostname_is_non_ascii() and g_hostname_is_ascii_encoded() to both return %TRUE for a name.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if @hostname contains any ASCII-encoded segments.

function.name: g_hostname_is_ip_address
function.description:
Tests if @hostname is the string form of an IPv4 or IPv6 address. (Eg, "192.168.0.1".)
Since 2.66, IPv6 addresses with a zone-id are accepted (RFC6874).
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.parameter_description: a hostname (or IP address in string form)

function.return: %TRUE if @hostname is an IP address

function.name: g_hostname_is_non_ascii
function.description:
Tests if @hostname contains Unicode characters. If this returns %TRUE, you need to encode the hostname with g_hostname_to_ascii() before using it in non-IDN-aware contexts.
Note that a hostname might contain a mix of encoded and unencoded segments, and so it is possible for g_hostname_is_non_ascii() and g_hostname_is_ascii_encoded() to both return %TRUE for a name.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if @hostname contains any non-ASCII characters

function.name: g_hostname_to_ascii
function.description:
Converts @hostname to its canonical ASCII form; an ASCII-only string containing no uppercase letters and not ending with a trailing dot.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.parameter_description: a valid UTF-8 or ASCII hostname

function.return: an ASCII hostname, which must be freed, or %NULL if @hostname is in some way invalid.

function.name: g_hostname_to_unicode
function.description:
Converts @hostname to its canonical presentation form; a UTF-8 string in Unicode normalization form C, containing no uppercase letters, no forbidden characters, and no ASCII-encoded segments, and not ending with a trailing dot.
Of course if @hostname is not an internationalized hostname, then the canonical presentation form will be entirely ASCII.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: hostname
parameter.parameter_description: a valid UTF-8 or ASCII hostname

function.return: a UTF-8 hostname, which must be freed, or %NULL if @hostname is in some way invalid.

function.name: g_htonl
function.description: Converts a 32-bit integer value from host to network byte order.

parameter.name: val
parameter.parameter_description: a 32-bit integer value in host byte order

function.return: @val converted to network byte order

function.name: g_htons
function.description: Converts a 16-bit integer value from host to network byte order.

parameter.name: val
parameter.parameter_description: a 16-bit integer value in host byte order

function.return: @val converted to network byte order

function.name: g_iconv
function.description:
Same as the standard UNIX routine iconv(), but may be implemented via libiconv on UNIX flavors that lack a native implementation.
GLib provides g_convert() and g_locale_to_utf8() which are likely more convenient than the raw iconv wrappers.
Note that the behaviour of iconv() for characters which are valid in the input character set, but which have no representation in the output character set, is implementation defined. This function may return success (with a positive number of non-reversible conversions as replacement characters were used), or it may return -1 and set an error such as %EILSEQ, in such a situation.
See [`iconv(3posix)`](man:iconv(3posix)) and [`iconv(3)`](man:iconv(3)) for more details about behavior when an error occurs.

parameter.name: inbytes_left
parameter.parameter_description: inout parameter, bytes remaining to convert in @inbuf

parameter.name: outbytes_left
parameter.parameter_description: inout parameter, bytes available to fill in @outbuf

function.return: count of non-reversible conversions, or -1 on error

function.name: g_iconv_close
function.description:
Same as the standard UNIX routine iconv_close(), but may be implemented via libiconv on UNIX flavors that lack a native implementation. Should be called to clean up the conversion descriptor from g_iconv_open() when you are done converting things.
GLib provides g_convert() and g_locale_to_utf8() which are likely more convenient than the raw iconv wrappers.
function.return: -1 on error, 0 on success

function.name: g_iconv_open
function.description:
Same as the standard UNIX routine iconv_open(), but may be implemented via libiconv on UNIX flavors that lack a native implementation.
GLib provides g_convert() and g_locale_to_utf8() which are likely more convenient than the raw iconv wrappers.
function.return: a "conversion descriptor", or (GIConv)-1 if opening the converter failed.

function.name: g_idle_add
function.description:
Adds a function to be called whenever there are no higher priority events pending to the default main loop.
The function is given the default idle priority, [const@GLib.PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE]. If the function returns [const@GLib.SOURCE_REMOVE] it is automatically removed from the list of event sources and will not be called again.
See [main loop memory management](main-loop.html#memory-management-of-sources) for details on how to handle the return value and memory management of @data.
This internally creates a main loop source using [func@GLib.idle_source_new] and attaches it to the global [struct@GLib.MainContext] using [method@GLib.Source.attach], so the callback will be invoked in whichever thread is running that main context. You can do these steps manually if you need greater control or to use a custom main context.
function.return: the ID (greater than 0) of the event source

function.name: g_idle_add_full
function.description:
Adds a function to be called whenever there are no higher priority events pending.
If the function returns [const@GLib.SOURCE_REMOVE] it is automatically removed from the list of event sources and will not be called again.
See [main loop memory management](main-loop.html#memory-management-of-sources) for details on how to handle the return value and memory management of @data.
This internally creates a main loop source using [func@GLib.idle_source_new] and attaches it to the global [struct@GLib.MainContext] using [method@GLib.Source.attach], so the callback will be invoked in whichever thread is running that main context. You can do these steps manually if you need greater control or to use a custom main context.

parameter.name: priority
parameter.parameter_description: the priority of the idle source; typically this will be in the range between [const@GLib.PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE] and [const@GLib.PRIORITY_HIGH_IDLE]

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: function to call when the idle is removed

function.return: the ID (greater than 0) of the event source

function.name: g_idle_add_once
function.description:
Adds a function to be called whenever there are no higher priority events pending to the default main loop.
The function is given the default idle priority, [const@GLib.PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE].
The function will only be called once and then the source will be automatically removed from the main context.
This function otherwise behaves like [func@GLib.idle_add].
Since: 2.74
function.return: the ID (greater than 0) of the event source

function.name: g_idle_remove_by_data
function.description: Removes the idle function with the given data.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the idle source’s callback.

function.return: true if an idle source was found and removed, false otherwise

function.name: g_idle_source_new
function.description:
Creates a new idle source.
The source will not initially be associated with any [struct@GLib.MainContext] and must be added to one with [method@GLib.Source.attach] before it will be executed. Note that the default priority for idle sources is [const@GLib.PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE], as compared to other sources which have a default priority of [const@GLib.PRIORITY_DEFAULT].
function.return: the newly-created idle source

function.name: g_info
function.description:
A convenience function/macro to log an informational message.
Seldom used.
If [func@GLib.log_default_handler] is used as the log handler function, a new-line character will automatically be appended to @..., and need not be entered manually.
Such messages are suppressed by the [func@GLib.log_default_handler] and [func@GLib.log_writer_default] unless the `G_MESSAGES_DEBUG` or `DEBUG_INVOCATION` environment variables are set appropriately. If you need to set the allowed domains at runtime, use [func@GLib.log_writer_default_set_debug_domains].
If structured logging is enabled, this will use [func@GLib.log_structured]; otherwise it will use [func@GLib.log]. See [Using Structured Logging](logging.html#using-structured-logging).
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: format string, followed by parameters to insert into the format string (as with `printf()`)

function.name: g_int64_equal
function.description:
Compares the two #gint64 values being pointed to and returns %TRUE if they are equal. It can be passed to g_hash_table_new() as the @key_equal_func parameter, when using non-%NULL pointers to 64-bit integers as keys in a #GHashTable.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: v2
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #gint64 key to compare with @v1

function.return: %TRUE if the two keys match.

function.name: g_int64_hash
function.description:
Converts a pointer to a #gint64 to a hash value.
It can be passed to g_hash_table_new() as the @hash_func parameter, when using non-%NULL pointers to 64-bit integer values as keys in a #GHashTable.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a hash value corresponding to the key.

function.name: g_int_equal
function.description:
Compares the two #gint values being pointed to and returns %TRUE if they are equal. It can be passed to g_hash_table_new() as the @key_equal_func parameter, when using non-%NULL pointers to integers as keys in a #GHashTable.
Note that this function acts on pointers to #gint, not on #gint directly: if your hash table's keys are of the form `GINT_TO_POINTER (n)`, use g_direct_equal() instead.

parameter.name: v2
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #gint key to compare with @v1

function.return: %TRUE if the two keys match.

function.name: g_int_hash
function.description:
Converts a pointer to a #gint to a hash value. It can be passed to g_hash_table_new() as the @hash_func parameter, when using non-%NULL pointers to integer values as keys in a #GHashTable.
Note that this function acts on pointers to #gint, not on #gint directly: if your hash table's keys are of the form `GINT_TO_POINTER (n)`, use g_direct_hash() instead.
function.return: a hash value corresponding to the key.

function.name: g_intern_static_string
function.description:
Returns a canonical representation for @string. Interned strings can be compared for equality by comparing the pointers, instead of using strcmp(). g_intern_static_string() does not copy the string, therefore @string must not be freed or modified.
This function must not be used before library constructors have finished running. In particular, this means it cannot be used to initialize global variables in C++.
Since: 2.10
function.return: a canonical representation for the string

function.name: g_intern_string
function.description:
Returns a canonical representation for @string. Interned strings can be compared for equality by comparing the pointers, instead of using strcmp().
This function must not be used before library constructors have finished running. In particular, this means it cannot be used to initialize global variables in C++.
Since: 2.10
function.return: a canonical representation for the string

function.name: g_io_add_watch
function.description: Adds the #GIOChannel into the default main loop context with the default priority.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the condition is satisfied

function.return: the event source id

function.name: g_io_add_watch_full
function.description:
Adds the #GIOChannel into the default main loop context with the given priority.
This internally creates a main loop source using g_io_create_watch() and attaches it to the main loop context with g_source_attach(). You can do these steps manually if you need greater control.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the condition is satisfied

parameter.name: notify
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call when the source is removed

function.return: the event source id

function.name: g_io_channel_close
function.description:
Close an IO channel. Any pending data to be written will be flushed, ignoring errors. The channel will not be freed until the last reference is dropped using g_io_channel_unref().
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_shutdown() instead.

function.name: g_io_channel_error_from_errno
function.description: Converts an `errno` error number to a #GIOChannelError.
function.return: a #GIOChannelError error number, e.g. %G_IO_CHANNEL_ERROR_INVAL.

function.name: g_io_channel_flush
function.description: Flushes the write buffer for the GIOChannel.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store an error of type #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation: One of %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL, %G_IO_STATUS_AGAIN, or %G_IO_STATUS_ERROR.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_buffer_condition
function.description: This function returns a #GIOCondition depending on whether there is data to be read/space to write data in the internal buffers in the #GIOChannel. Only the flags %G_IO_IN and %G_IO_OUT may be set.
function.return: A #GIOCondition

function.name: g_io_channel_get_buffer_size
function.description: Gets the buffer size.
function.return: the size of the buffer.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_buffered
function.description: Returns whether @channel is buffered.
function.return: %TRUE if the @channel is buffered.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_close_on_unref
function.description: Returns whether the file/socket/whatever associated with @channel will be closed when @channel receives its final unref and is destroyed. The default value of this is %TRUE for channels created by g_io_channel_new_file (), and %FALSE for all other channels.
function.return: %TRUE if the channel will be closed, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_encoding
function.description: Gets the encoding for the input/output of the channel. The internal encoding is always UTF-8. The encoding %NULL makes the channel safe for binary data.
function.return: A string containing the encoding, this string is owned by GLib and must not be freed.

function.name: g_io_channel_get_flags
function.description:
Gets the current flags for a #GIOChannel, including read-only flags such as %G_IO_FLAG_IS_READABLE.
The values of the flags %G_IO_FLAG_IS_READABLE and %G_IO_FLAG_IS_WRITABLE are cached for internal use by the channel when it is created. If they should change at some later point (e.g. partial shutdown of a socket with the UNIX shutdown() function), the user should immediately call g_io_channel_get_flags() to update the internal values of these flags.
function.return: the flags which are set on the channel

function.name: g_io_channel_get_line_term
function.description: This returns the string that #GIOChannel uses to determine where in the file a line break occurs. A value of %NULL indicates autodetection. Since 2.84, the return value is always nul-terminated.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return the length of the line terminator

function.return: The line termination string. This value is owned by GLib and must not be freed.

function.name: g_io_channel_init
function.description:
Initializes a #GIOChannel struct.
This is called by each of the above functions when creating a #GIOChannel, and so is not often needed by the application programmer (unless you are creating a new type of #GIOChannel).

function.name: g_io_channel_new_file
function.description: Open a file @filename as a #GIOChannel using mode @mode. This channel will be closed when the last reference to it is dropped, so there is no need to call g_io_channel_close() (though doing so will not cause problems, as long as no attempt is made to access the channel after it is closed).

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: A string containing the name of a file

parameter.name: mode
parameter.parameter_description: One of "r", "w", "a", "r+", "w+", "a+". These have the same meaning as in fopen()

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type %G_FILE_ERROR

function.return: A #GIOChannel on success, %NULL on failure.

function.name: g_io_channel_read
function.description:
Reads data from a #GIOChannel.
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_read_chars() instead.

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a buffer to read the data into (which should be at least count bytes long)

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to read from the #GIOChannel

parameter.name: bytes_read
parameter.parameter_description: returns the number of bytes actually read

function.return: %G_IO_ERROR_NONE if the operation was successful.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_chars
function.description: Replacement for g_io_channel_read() with the new API.

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a buffer to read data into

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the buffer. Note that the buffer may not be completely filled even if there is data in the buffer if the remaining data is not a complete character.

parameter.name: bytes_read
parameter.parameter_description: The number of bytes read. This may be zero even on success if count < 6 and the channel's encoding is non-%NULL. This indicates that the next UTF-8 character is too wide for the buffer.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError.

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_line
function.description: Reads a line, including the terminating character(s), from a #GIOChannel into a newly-allocated string. @str_return will contain allocated memory if the return is %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL.

parameter.name: str_return
parameter.parameter_description: The line read from the #GIOChannel, including the line terminator. This data should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed. This is a nul-terminated string. If a @length of zero is returned, this will be %NULL instead.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: location to store length of the read data, or %NULL

parameter.name: terminator_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store position of line terminator, or %NULL

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_line_string
function.description: Reads a line from a #GIOChannel, using a #GString as a buffer.

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: a #GString into which the line will be written. If @buffer already contains data, the old data will be overwritten.

parameter.name: terminator_pos
parameter.parameter_description: location to store position of line terminator, or %NULL

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_to_end
function.description: Reads all the remaining data from the file.

parameter.name: str_return
parameter.parameter_description: Location to store a pointer to a string holding the remaining data in the #GIOChannel. This data should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed. This data is terminated by an extra nul character, but there may be other nuls in the intervening data.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: location to store length of the data

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL on success. This function never returns %G_IO_STATUS_EOF.

function.name: g_io_channel_read_unichar
function.description: Reads a Unicode character from @channel. This function cannot be called on a channel with %NULL encoding.

parameter.name: thechar
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return a character

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: a #GIOStatus

function.name: g_io_channel_ref
function.description: Increments the reference count of a #GIOChannel.
function.return: the @channel that was passed in (since 2.6)

function.name: g_io_channel_seek
function.description:
Sets the current position in the #GIOChannel, similar to the standard library function fseek().
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_seek_position() instead.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: an offset, in bytes, which is added to the position specified by @type

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the position in the file, which can be %G_SEEK_CUR (the current position), %G_SEEK_SET (the start of the file), or %G_SEEK_END (the end of the file)

function.return: %G_IO_ERROR_NONE if the operation was successful.

function.name: g_io_channel_seek_position
function.description: Replacement for g_io_channel_seek() with the new API.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: The offset in bytes from the position specified by @type

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSeekType. The type %G_SEEK_CUR is only allowed in those cases where a call to g_io_channel_set_encoding () is allowed. See the documentation for g_io_channel_set_encoding () for details.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_set_buffer_size
function.description: Sets the buffer size.

parameter.name: size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the buffer, or 0 to let GLib pick a good size

function.name: g_io_channel_set_buffered
function.description:
The buffering state can only be set if the channel's encoding is %NULL. For any other encoding, the channel must be buffered.
A buffered channel can only be set unbuffered if the channel's internal buffers have been flushed. Newly created channels or channels which have returned %G_IO_STATUS_EOF not require such a flush. For write-only channels, a call to g_io_channel_flush () is sufficient. For all other channels, the buffers may be flushed by a call to g_io_channel_seek_position (). This includes the possibility of seeking with seek type %G_SEEK_CUR and an offset of zero. Note that this means that socket-based channels cannot be set unbuffered once they have had data read from them.
On unbuffered channels, it is safe to mix read and write calls from the new and old APIs, if this is necessary for maintaining old code.
The default state of the channel is buffered.

parameter.name: buffered
parameter.parameter_description: whether to set the channel buffered or unbuffered

function.name: g_io_channel_set_close_on_unref
function.description:
Whether to close the channel on the final unref of the #GIOChannel data structure. The default value of this is %TRUE for channels created by g_io_channel_new_file (), and %FALSE for all other channels.
Setting this flag to %TRUE for a channel you have already closed can cause problems when the final reference to the #GIOChannel is dropped.

parameter.name: do_close
parameter.parameter_description: Whether to close the channel on the final unref of the GIOChannel data structure.

function.name: g_io_channel_set_encoding
function.description:
Sets the encoding for the input/output of the channel. The internal encoding is always UTF-8. The default encoding for the external file is UTF-8.
The encoding %NULL is safe to use with binary data.
The encoding can only be set if one of the following conditions is true:
- The channel was just created, and has not been written to or read from yet.
- The channel is write-only.
- The channel is a file, and the file pointer was just repositioned by a call to g_io_channel_seek_position(). (This flushes all the internal buffers.)
- The current encoding is %NULL or UTF-8.
- One of the (new API) read functions has just returned %G_IO_STATUS_EOF (or, in the case of g_io_channel_read_to_end(), %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL).
- One of the functions g_io_channel_read_chars() or g_io_channel_read_unichar() has returned %G_IO_STATUS_AGAIN or %G_IO_STATUS_ERROR. This may be useful in the case of %G_CONVERT_ERROR_ILLEGAL_SEQUENCE. Returning one of these statuses from g_io_channel_read_line(), g_io_channel_read_line_string(), or g_io_channel_read_to_end() does not guarantee that the encoding can be changed.
Channels which do not meet one of the above conditions cannot call g_io_channel_seek_position() with an offset of %G_SEEK_CUR, and, if they are "seekable", cannot call g_io_channel_write_chars() after calling one of the API "read" functions.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store an error of type #GConvertError

function.return: %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL if the encoding was successfully set

function.name: g_io_channel_set_flags
function.description: Sets the (writeable) flags in @channel to (@flags & %G_IO_FLAG_SET_MASK).

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: the flags to set on the IO channel

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: A location to return an error of type #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_set_line_term
function.description: This sets the string that #GIOChannel uses to determine where in the file a line break occurs.

parameter.name: line_term
parameter.parameter_description: The line termination string. Use %NULL for autodetect. Autodetection breaks on "\n", "\r\n", "\r", "\0", and the Unicode paragraph separator. Autodetection should not be used for anything other than file-based channels.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: The length of the termination string. If -1 is passed, the string is assumed to be nul-terminated. This option allows termination strings with embedded nuls.

function.name: g_io_channel_shutdown
function.description: Close an IO channel. Any pending data to be written will be flushed if @flush is %TRUE. The channel will not be freed until the last reference is dropped using g_io_channel_unref().
function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_unix_get_fd
function.description:
Returns the file descriptor of the #GIOChannel.
On Windows this function returns the file descriptor or socket of the #GIOChannel.
function.return: the file descriptor of the #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_unix_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a file descriptor. On UNIX systems this works for plain files, pipes, and sockets.
The returned #GIOChannel has a reference count of 1.
The default encoding for #GIOChannel is UTF-8. If your application is reading output from a command using via pipe, you may need to set the encoding to the encoding of the current locale (see g_get_charset()) with the g_io_channel_set_encoding() function. By default, the fd passed will not be closed when the final reference to the #GIOChannel data structure is dropped.
If you want to read raw binary data without interpretation, then call the g_io_channel_set_encoding() function with %NULL for the encoding argument.
This function is available in GLib on Windows, too, but you should avoid using it on Windows. The domain of file descriptors and sockets overlap. There is no way for GLib to know which one you mean in case the argument you pass to this function happens to be both a valid file descriptor and socket. If that happens a warning is issued, and GLib assumes that it is the file descriptor you mean.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_unref
function.description: Decrements the reference count of a #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_win32_new_fd
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a file descriptor on Windows. This works for file descriptors from the C runtime.
This function works for file descriptors as returned by the open(), creat(), pipe() and fileno() calls in the Microsoft C runtime. In order to meaningfully use this function your code should use the same C runtime as GLib uses, which is msvcrt.dll. Note that in current Microsoft compilers it is near impossible to convince it to build code that would use msvcrt.dll. The last Microsoft compiler version that supported using msvcrt.dll as the C runtime was version 6. The GNU compiler and toolchain for Windows, also known as Mingw, fully supports msvcrt.dll.
If you have created a #GIOChannel for a file descriptor and started watching (polling) it, you shouldn't call read() on the file descriptor. This is because adding polling for a file descriptor is implemented in GLib on Windows by starting a thread that sits blocked in a read() from the file descriptor most of the time. All reads from the file descriptor should be done by this internal GLib thread. Your code should call only g_io_channel_read().
This function is available only in GLib on Windows.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_win32_new_messages
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a window handle on Windows.
This function creates a #GIOChannel that can be used to poll for Windows messages for the window in question.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel.

function.name: g_io_channel_win32_new_socket
function.description:
Creates a new #GIOChannel given a socket on Windows.
This function works for sockets created by Winsock. It's available only in GLib on Windows.
Polling a #GSource created to watch a channel for a socket puts the socket in non-blocking mode. This is a side-effect of the implementation and unavoidable.
function.return: a new #GIOChannel

function.name: g_io_channel_write
function.description:
Writes data to a #GIOChannel.
Deprecated:2.2: Use g_io_channel_write_chars() instead.

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: the buffer containing the data to write

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to write

parameter.name: bytes_written
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes actually written

function.return: %G_IO_ERROR_NONE if the operation was successful.

function.name: g_io_channel_write_chars
function.description:
Replacement for g_io_channel_write() with the new API.
On seekable channels with encodings other than %NULL or UTF-8, generic mixing of reading and writing is not allowed. A call to g_io_channel_write_chars () may only be made on a channel from which data has been read in the cases described in the documentation for g_io_channel_set_encoding ().

parameter.name: buf
parameter.parameter_description: a buffer to write data from

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the buffer. If -1, the buffer is taken to be a nul-terminated string.

parameter.name: bytes_written
parameter.parameter_description: The number of bytes written. This can be nonzero even if the return value is not %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL. If the return value is %G_IO_STATUS_NORMAL and the channel is blocking, this will always be equal to @count if @count >= 0.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: the status of the operation.

function.name: g_io_channel_write_unichar
function.description: Writes a Unicode character to @channel. This function cannot be called on a channel with %NULL encoding.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to return an error of type #GConvertError or #GIOChannelError

function.return: a #GIOStatus

function.name: g_io_create_watch
function.description:
Creates a #GSource that's dispatched when @condition is met for the given @channel. For example, if condition is %G_IO_IN, the source will be dispatched when there's data available for reading.
The callback function invoked by the #GSource should be added with g_source_set_callback(), but it has type #GIOFunc (not #GSourceFunc).
g_io_add_watch() is a simpler interface to this same functionality, for the case where you want to add the source to the default main loop context at the default priority.
On Windows, polling a #GSource created to watch a channel for a socket puts the socket in non-blocking mode. This is a side-effect of the implementation and unavoidable.
function.return: a new #GSource

function.name: g_key_file_free
function.description:
Clears all keys and groups from @key_file, and decreases the reference count by 1.
If the reference count reaches zero, frees the key file and all its allocated memory.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_get_boolean
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as a boolean.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. Likewise, if the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted as a boolean then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.INVALID_VALUE] is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the value associated with the key as a boolean, or false if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_boolean_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name as booleans.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. Likewise, if the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted as booleans then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.INVALID_VALUE] is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the values associated with the key as a list of booleans, or `NULL` if the key was not found or could not be parsed. The returned list of booleans should be freed with [func@GLib.free] when no longer needed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_comment
function.description:
Retrieves a comment above @key from @group_name.
If @key is `NULL` then @comment will be read from above @group_name. If both @key and @group_name are `NULL`, then @comment will be read from above the first group in the file.
Note that the returned string does not include the `#` comment markers, but does include any whitespace after them (on each line). It includes the line breaks between lines, but does not include the final line break.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: group_name
parameter.parameter_description: a group name, or `NULL` to get a top-level comment

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: a key, or `NULL` to get a group comment

function.return: a comment that should be freed with [func@GLib.free]

function.name: g_key_file_get_double
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as a double.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. Likewise, if the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted as a double then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.INVALID_VALUE] is returned.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the value associated with the key as a double, or `0.0` if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_double_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name as doubles.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. Likewise, if the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted as doubles then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.INVALID_VALUE] is returned.
Since: 2.12
function.return: the values associated with the key as a list of doubles, or `NULL` if the key was not found or could not be parsed. The returned list of doubles should be freed with [func@GLib.free] when no longer needed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_groups
function.description:
Returns all groups in the key file loaded with @key_file.
The array of returned groups will be `NULL`-terminated, so @length may optionally be `NULL`.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned groups, or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: a newly-allocated `NULL`-terminated array of strings. Use [func@GLib.strfreev] to free it.

function.name: g_key_file_get_int64
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as a signed 64-bit integer.
This is similar to [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_integer] but can return 64-bit results without truncation.
Since: 2.26
function.return: the value associated with the key as a signed 64-bit integer, or `0` if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_integer
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as an integer.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. Likewise, if the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted as an integer, or is out of range for a `gint`, then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.INVALID_VALUE] is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the value associated with the key as an integer, or `0` if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_integer_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name as integers.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. Likewise, if the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted as integers, or are out of range for `gint`, then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.INVALID_VALUE] is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: the values associated with the key as a list of integers, or `NULL` if the key was not found or could not be parsed. The returned list of integers should be freed with [func@GLib.free] when no longer needed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_keys
function.description:
Returns all keys for the group name @group_name.
The array of returned keys will be `NULL`-terminated, so @length may optionally be `NULL`. If the @group_name cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.GROUP_NOT_FOUND] is returned.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of keys returned, or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: a newly-allocated `NULL`-terminated array of strings. Use [func@GLib.strfreev] to free it.

function.name: g_key_file_get_locale_for_key
function.description:
Returns the actual locale which the result of [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_locale_string] or [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_locale_string_list] came from.
If calling [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_locale_string] or [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_locale_string_list] with exactly the same @key_file, @group_name, @key and @locale, the result of those functions will have originally been tagged with the locale that is the result of this function.
Since: 2.56

parameter.name: locale
parameter.parameter_description: a locale identifier or `NULL` to use the current locale

function.return: the locale from the file, or `NULL` if the key was not found or the entry in the file was was untranslated

function.name: g_key_file_get_locale_string
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name translated in the given @locale if available.
If @locale is `C` then the untranslated value is returned (since GLib 2.84).
If @locale is `NULL` then the current locale is assumed.
If @locale is to be non-`NULL`, or if the current locale will change over the lifetime of the [struct@GLib.KeyFile], it must be loaded with [flags@GLib.KeyFileFlags.KEEP_TRANSLATIONS] in order to load strings for all locales.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. If the value associated with @key cannot be interpreted or no suitable translation can be found then the untranslated value is returned.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: locale
parameter.parameter_description: a locale identifier or `NULL` to use the current locale

function.return: a newly allocated string or `NULL` if the specified key cannot be found.

function.name: g_key_file_get_locale_string_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name translated in the given @locale if available.
If @locale is `C` then the untranslated value is returned (since GLib 2.84).
If @locale is `NULL` then the current locale is assumed.
If @locale is to be non-`NULL`, or if the current locale will change over the lifetime of the [struct@GLib.KeyFile], it must be loaded with [flags@GLib.KeyFileFlags.KEEP_TRANSLATIONS] in order to load strings for all locales.
If @key cannot be found then [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. If the values associated with @key cannot be interpreted or no suitable translations can be found then the untranslated values are returned. The returned array is `NULL`-terminated, so @length may optionally be `NULL`.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: locale
parameter.parameter_description: a locale identifier or `NULL` to use the current locale

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned strings or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: a newly allocated `NULL`-terminated string array or `NULL` if the key isn’t found. The string array should be freed with [func@GLib.strfreev].

function.name: g_key_file_get_start_group
function.description:
Returns the name of the start group of the file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: The start group of the key file.

function.name: g_key_file_get_string
function.description:
Returns the string value associated with @key under @group_name.
Unlike [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_value], this function handles escape sequences like `\s`.
If the key cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. If the @group_name cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.GROUP_NOT_FOUND] is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a newly allocated string or `NULL` if the specified key cannot be found.

function.name: g_key_file_get_string_list
function.description:
Returns the values associated with @key under @group_name.
If the key cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. If the @group_name cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.GROUP_NOT_FOUND] is returned.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned strings, or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: a `NULL`-terminated string array or `NULL` if the specified key cannot be found. The array should be freed with [func@GLib.strfreev].

function.name: g_key_file_get_uint64
function.description:
Returns the value associated with @key under @group_name as an unsigned 64-bit integer.
This is similar to [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_integer] but can return large positive results without truncation.
Since: 2.26
function.return: the value associated with the key as an unsigned 64-bit integer, or `0` if the key was not found or could not be parsed.

function.name: g_key_file_get_value
function.description:
Returns the raw value associated with @key under @group_name.
Use [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_string] to retrieve an unescaped UTF-8 string.
If the key cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.KEY_NOT_FOUND] is returned. If the @group_name cannot be found, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.GROUP_NOT_FOUND] is returned.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a newly allocated string or `NULL` if the specified key cannot be found.

function.name: g_key_file_has_group
function.description:
Looks whether the key file has the group @group_name.
Since: 2.6
function.return: true if @group_name is a part of @key_file, false otherwise.

function.name: g_key_file_has_key
function.description:
Looks whether the key file has the key @key in the group @group_name.
Note that this function does not follow the rules for [struct@GLib.Error] strictly; the return value both carries meaning and signals an error. To use this function, you must pass a [struct@GLib.Error] pointer in @error, and check whether it is not `NULL` to see if an error occurred.
Language bindings should use [method@GLib.KeyFile.get_value] to test whether a key exists.
Since: 2.6
function.return: true if @key is a part of @group_name, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_bytes
function.description:
Loads a key file from the data in @bytes into an empty [struct@GLib.KeyFile] structure.
If the object cannot be created then a [error@GLib.KeyFileError] is returned.
Since: 2.50
function.return: true if a key file could be loaded, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_data
function.description:
Loads a key file from memory into an empty [struct@GLib.KeyFile] structure.
If the object cannot be created then a [error@GLib.KeyFileError is returned.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @data in bytes (or `(gsize)-1` if data is nul-terminated)

function.return: true if a key file could be loaded, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_data_dirs
function.description:
Looks for a key file named @file in the paths returned from [func@GLib.get_user_data_dir] and [func@GLib.get_system_data_dirs].
The search algorithm from [method@GLib.KeyFile.load_from_dirs] is used. If @file is found, it’s loaded into @key_file and its full path is returned in @full_path.
If the file could not be loaded then either a [error@GLib.FileError] or [error@GLib.KeyFileError] is returned.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: a relative path to a filename to open and parse

parameter.name: full_path
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a string containing the full path of the file, or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: true if a key file could be loaded, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_dirs
function.description:
Looks for a key file named @file in the paths specified in @search_dirs, loads the file into @key_file and returns the file’s full path in @full_path.
@search_dirs are checked in the order listed in the array, with the highest priority directory listed first. Within each directory, @file is looked for. If it’s not found, `-` characters in @file are progressively replaced with directory separators to search subdirectories of the search directory. If the file has not been found after all `-` characters have been replaced, the next search directory in @search_dirs is checked.
If the file could not be found in any of the @search_dirs, [error@GLib.KeyFileError.NOT_FOUND] is returned. If the file is found but the OS returns an error when opening or reading the file, a [error@GLib.FileError] is returned. If there is a problem parsing the file, a [error@GLib.KeyFileError] is returned.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: a relative path to a filename to open and parse

parameter.name: full_path
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a string containing the full path of the file, or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: true if a key file could be loaded, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_load_from_file
function.description:
Loads a key file into an empty [struct@GLib.KeyFile] structure.
If the OS returns an error when opening or reading the file, a [error@GLib.FileError] is returned. If there is a problem parsing the file, a [error@GLib.KeyFileError] is returned.
This function will never return a [error@GLib.KeyFileError.NOT_FOUND] error. If the @file is not found, [error@GLib.FileError.NOENT] is returned.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: file
parameter.parameter_description: the path of a filename to load, in the GLib filename encoding

function.return: true if a key file could be loaded, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_new
function.description:
Creates a new empty [struct@GLib.KeyFile] object.
Use [method@GLib.KeyFile.load_from_file], [method@GLib.KeyFile.load_from_data], [method@GLib.KeyFile.load_from_dirs] or [method@GLib.KeyFile.load_from_data_dirs] to read an existing key file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: an empty [struct@GLib.KeyFile].

function.name: g_key_file_ref
function.description:
Increases the reference count of @key_file.
Since: 2.32
function.return: the same @key_file.

function.name: g_key_file_remove_comment
function.description:
Removes a comment above @key from @group_name.
If @key is `NULL` then @comment will be removed above @group_name. If both @key and @group_name are `NULL`, then @comment will be removed above the first group in the file.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: group_name
parameter.parameter_description: a group name, or `NULL` to get a top-level comment

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: a key, or `NULL` to get a group comment

function.return: true if the comment was removed, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_remove_group
function.description:
Removes the specified group, @group_name, from the key file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: true if the group was removed, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_remove_key
function.description:
Removes @key in @group_name from the key file.
Since: 2.6
function.return: true if the key was removed, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_save_to_file
function.description:
Writes the contents of @key_file to @filename using [func@GLib.file_set_contents].
If you need stricter guarantees about durability of the written file than are provided by [func@GLib.file_set_contents], use [func@GLib.file_set_contents_full] with the return value of [method@GLib.KeyFile.to_data].
This function can fail for any of the reasons that [func@GLib.file_set_contents] may fail.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the file to write to

function.return: true if successful, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_set_boolean
function.description:
Associates a new boolean value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_boolean_list
function.description:
Associates a list of boolean values with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_comment
function.description:
Places a comment above @key from @group_name.
If @key is `NULL` then @comment will be written above @group_name. If both @key and @group_name are `NULL`, then @comment will be written above the first group in the file.
Passing a non-existent @group_name or @key to this function returns false and populates @error. (In contrast, passing a non-existent `group_name` or `key` to [method@GLib.KeyFile.set_string] creates the associated group name and key.)
Note that this function prepends a `#` comment marker to each line of @comment.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: group_name
parameter.parameter_description: a group name, or `NULL` to write a top-level comment

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: a key, or `NULL` to write a group comment

function.return: true if the comment was written, false otherwise

function.name: g_key_file_set_double
function.description:
Associates a new double value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.12

function.name: g_key_file_set_double_list
function.description:
Associates a list of double values with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.12

function.name: g_key_file_set_int64
function.description:
Associates a new integer value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_key_file_set_integer
function.description:
Associates a new integer value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_integer_list
function.description:
Associates a list of integer values with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_list_separator
function.description:
Sets the character which is used to separate values in lists.
Typically `;` or `,` are used as separators. The default list separator is `;`.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_locale_string
function.description:
Associates a string value for @key and @locale under @group_name.
If the translation for @key cannot be found then it is created.
If @locale is `C` then the untranslated value is set (since GLib 2.84).
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_locale_string_list
function.description:
Associates a list of string values for @key and @locale under @group_name.
If @locale is `C` then the untranslated value is set (since GLib 2.84).
If the translation for @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a `NULL`-terminated array of locale string values

function.name: g_key_file_set_string
function.description:
Associates a new string value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name cannot be found then it is created. Unlike [method@GLib.KeyFile.set_value], this function handles characters that need escaping, such as newlines.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_string_list
function.description:
Associates a list of string values for @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_set_uint64
function.description:
Associates a new integer value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_key_file_set_value
function.description:
Associates a new value with @key under @group_name.
If @key cannot be found then it is created. If @group_name cannot be found then it is created. To set an UTF-8 string which may contain characters that need escaping (such as newlines or spaces), use [method@GLib.KeyFile.set_string].
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_key_file_to_data
function.description:
Outputs @key_file as a string.
Note that this function never reports an error.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the length of the returned string, or `NULL` to ignore

function.return: a newly allocated string holding the contents of the key file

function.name: g_key_file_unref
function.description:
Decreases the reference count of @key_file by 1.
If the reference count reaches zero, frees the key file and all its allocated memory.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_list_alloc
function.description: Allocates space for one #GList element. It is called by g_list_append(), g_list_prepend(), g_list_insert() and g_list_insert_sorted() and so is rarely used on its own.
function.return: a pointer to the newly-allocated #GList element

function.name: g_list_append

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: either @list or the new start of the #GList if @list was %NULL

function.name: g_list_concat

parameter.name: list1
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: list2
parameter.parameter_description: the #GList to add to the end of the first #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the start of the new #GList, which equals @list1 if not %NULL

function.name: g_list_copy
function.description:
Copies a #GList.
Note that this is a "shallow" copy. If the list elements consist of pointers to data, the pointers are copied but the actual data is not. See g_list_copy_deep() if you need to copy the data as well.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the start of the new list that holds the same data as @list

function.name: g_list_copy_deep
function.description:
Makes a full (deep) copy of a #GList.
In contrast with g_list_copy(), this function uses @func to make a copy of each list element, in addition to copying the list container itself.
@func, as a #GCopyFunc, takes two arguments, the data to be copied and a @user_data pointer. On common processor architectures, it's safe to pass %NULL as @user_data if the copy function takes only one argument. You may get compiler warnings from this though if compiling with GCC’s `-Wcast-function-type` warning.
For instance, if @list holds a list of GObjects, you can do: |[<!-- language="C" --> another_list = g_list_copy_deep (list, (GCopyFunc) g_object_ref, NULL); ]|
And, to entirely free the new list, you could do: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_list_free_full (another_list, g_object_unref); ]|
Since: 2.34

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a copy function used to copy every element in the list

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the copy function @func, or %NULL

function.return: the start of the new list that holds a full copy of @list, use g_list_free_full() to free it

function.name: g_list_delete_link
function.description: Removes the node link_ from the list and frees it. Compare this to g_list_remove_link() which removes the node without freeing it.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_find
function.description: Finds the element in a #GList which contains the given data.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the found #GList element, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_list_find_custom
function.description: Finds an element in a #GList, using a supplied function to find the desired element. It iterates over the list, calling the given function which should return 0 when the desired element is found. The function takes two #gconstpointer arguments, the #GList element's data as the first argument and the given user data.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data passed to the function

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element. It should return 0 when the desired element is found

function.return: the found #GList element, or %NULL if it is not found

function.name: g_list_first
function.description: Gets the first element in a #GList.
function.return: the first element in the #GList, or %NULL if the #GList has no elements

function.name: g_list_foreach
function.description:
Calls a function for each element of a #GList.
It is safe for @func to remove the element from @list, but it must not modify any part of the list after that element.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call with each element's data

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the function

function.name: g_list_free
function.description:
Frees all of the memory used by a #GList. The freed elements are returned to the slice allocator.
If list elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, you should either use g_list_free_full() or free them manually first.
It can be combined with g_steal_pointer() to ensure the list head pointer is not left dangling: |[<!-- language="C" --> GList *list_of_borrowed_things = …; /<!-- -->* (transfer container) *<!-- -->/ g_list_free (g_steal_pointer (&list_of_borrowed_things)); ]|

function.name: g_list_free1
function.description: Another name for g_list_free_1().

function.name: g_list_free_1
function.description:
Frees one #GList element, but does not update links from the next and previous elements in the list, so you should not call this function on an element that is currently part of a list.
It is usually used after g_list_remove_link().

function.name: g_list_free_full

parameter.name: free_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to be called to free each element's data

function.name: g_list_index
function.description: Gets the position of the element containing the given data (starting from 0).

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the index of the element containing the data, or -1 if the data is not found

function.name: g_list_insert
function.description: Inserts a new element into the list at the given position.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: position
parameter.parameter_description: the position to insert the element. If this is negative, or is larger than the number of elements in the list, the new element is added on to the end of the list.

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_before
function.description: Inserts a new element into the list before the given position.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: the list element before which the new element is inserted or %NULL to insert at the end of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_before_link
function.description:
Inserts @link_ into the list before the given position.
Since: 2.62

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: the list element before which the new element is inserted or %NULL to insert at the end of the list

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: the list element to be added, which must not be part of any other list

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_sorted
function.description:
Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.
If you are adding many new elements to a list, and the number of new elements is much larger than the length of the list, use g_list_prepend() to add the new items and sort the list afterwards with g_list_sort().

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the already sorted list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_insert_sorted_with_data
function.description:
Inserts a new element into the list, using the given comparison function to determine its position.
If you are adding many new elements to a list, and the number of new elements is much larger than the length of the list, use g_list_prepend() to add the new items and sort the list afterwards with g_list_sort().
Since: 2.10

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the already sorted list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to compare elements in the list. It should return a number > 0 if the first parameter comes after the second parameter in the sort order.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to comparison function

function.return: the (possibly changed) start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_last
function.description: Gets the last element in a #GList.
function.return: the last element in the #GList, or %NULL if the #GList has no elements

function.name: g_list_length
function.description:
Gets the number of elements in a #GList.
This function iterates over the whole list to count its elements. Use a #GQueue instead of a GList if you regularly need the number of items. To check whether the list is non-empty, it is faster to check @list against %NULL.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the number of elements in the #GList

function.name: g_list_next
function.return: the next element, or %NULL if there are no more elements

function.name: g_list_nth
function.description:
Gets the element at the given position in a #GList.
This iterates over the list until it reaches the @n-th position. If you intend to iterate over every element, it is better to use a for-loop as described in the #GList introduction.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the position of the element, counting from 0

function.return: the element, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GList

function.name: g_list_nth_data
function.description:
Gets the data of the element at the given position.
This iterates over the list until it reaches the @n-th position. If you intend to iterate over every element, it is better to use a for-loop as described in the #GList introduction.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the element's data, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GList

function.name: g_list_nth_prev
function.description: Gets the element @n places before @list.

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the position of the element, counting from 0

function.return: the element, or %NULL if the position is off the end of the #GList

function.name: g_list_pop_allocator
function.description: Deprecated: 2.10

function.name: g_list_position
function.description: Gets the position of the given element in the #GList (starting from 0).

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

function.return: the position of the element in the #GList, or -1 if the element is not found

function.name: g_list_prepend

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.return: a pointer to the newly prepended element, which is the new start of the #GList

function.name: g_list_previous
function.return: the previous element, or %NULL if there are no previous elements

function.name: g_list_push_allocator
function.description: Deprecated: 2.10

function.name: g_list_remove
function.description: Removes an element from a #GList. If two elements contain the same data, only the first is removed. If none of the elements contain the data, the #GList is unchanged.

parameter.name: list
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList, this must point to the top of the list

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data of the element to remove
