Note that the @parameter_string is translated using the function set with g_option_context_set_translate_func(), so it should normally be passed untranslated.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: parameter_string
parameter.parameter_description: a string which is displayed in the first line of `--help` output, after the usage summary `programname [OPTION...]`

function.return: a newly created #GOptionContext, which must be freed with g_option_context_free() after use.

function.name: g_option_context_parse
function.description:
Parses the command line arguments, recognizing options which have been added to @context. A side-effect of calling this function is that g_set_prgname() will be called.
If the parsing is successful, any parsed arguments are removed from the array and @argc and @argv are updated accordingly. A '--' option is stripped from @argv unless there are unparsed options before and after it, or some of the options after it start with '-'. In case of an error, @argc and @argv are left unmodified.
If automatic `--help` support is enabled (see g_option_context_set_help_enabled()), and the @argv array contains one of the recognized help options, this function will produce help output to stdout and call `exit (0)`.
Note that function depends on the [current locale](running.html#locale) for automatic character set conversion of string and filename arguments.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: argc
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the number of command line arguments

parameter.name: argv
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the array of command line arguments

function.return: %TRUE if the parsing was successful, %FALSE if an error occurred

function.name: g_option_context_parse_strv
function.description:
Parses the command line arguments.
This function is similar to g_option_context_parse() except that it respects the normal memory rules when dealing with a strv instead of assuming that the passed-in array is the argv of the main function.
In particular, strings that are removed from the arguments list will be freed using g_free().
On Windows, the strings are expected to be in UTF-8. This is in contrast to g_option_context_parse() which expects them to be in the system codepage, which is how they are passed as @argv to main(). See g_win32_get_command_line() for a solution.
This function is useful if you are trying to use #GOptionContext with #GApplication.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: arguments
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the command line arguments (which must be in UTF-8 on Windows). Starting with GLib 2.62, @arguments can be %NULL, which matches g_option_context_parse().

function.return: %TRUE if the parsing was successful, %FALSE if an error occurred

function.name: g_option_context_set_description
function.description:
Adds a string to be displayed in `--help` output after the list of options. This text often includes a bug reporting address.
Note that the summary is translated (see g_option_context_set_translate_func()).
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: description
parameter.parameter_description: a string to be shown in `--help` output after the list of options, or %NULL

function.name: g_option_context_set_help_enabled
function.description:
Enables or disables automatic generation of `--help` output. By default, g_option_context_parse() recognizes `--help`, `-h`, `-?`, `--help-all` and `--help-groupname` and creates suitable output to stdout.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_option_context_set_ignore_unknown_options
function.description:
Sets whether to ignore unknown options or not. If an argument is ignored, it is left in the @argv array after parsing. By default, g_option_context_parse() treats unknown options as error.
This setting does not affect non-option arguments (i.e. arguments which don't start with a dash). But note that GOption cannot reliably determine whether a non-option belongs to a preceding unknown option.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: ignore_unknown
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to ignore unknown options, %FALSE to produce an error when unknown options are met

function.name: g_option_context_set_main_group
function.description:
Sets a #GOptionGroup as main group of the @context. This has the same effect as calling g_option_context_add_group(), the only difference is that the options in the main group are treated differently when generating `--help` output.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: group
parameter.parameter_description: the group to set as main group

function.name: g_option_context_set_strict_posix
function.description:
Sets strict POSIX mode.
By default, this mode is disabled.
In strict POSIX mode, the first non-argument parameter encountered (eg: filename) terminates argument processing. Remaining arguments are treated as non-options and are not attempted to be parsed.
If strict POSIX mode is disabled then parsing is done in the GNU way where option arguments can be freely mixed with non-options.
As an example, consider "ls foo -l". With GNU style parsing, this will list "foo" in long mode. In strict POSIX style, this will list the files named "foo" and "-l".
It may be useful to force strict POSIX mode when creating "verb style" command line tools. For example, the "gsettings" command line tool supports the global option "--schemadir" as well as many subcommands ("get", "set", etc.) which each have their own set of arguments. Using strict POSIX mode will allow parsing the global options up to the verb name while leaving the remaining options to be parsed by the relevant subcommand (which can be determined by examining the verb name, which should be present in argv[1] after parsing).
Since: 2.44

function.name: g_option_context_set_summary
function.description:
Adds a string to be displayed in `--help` output before the list of options. This is typically a summary of the program functionality.
Note that the summary is translated (see g_option_context_set_translate_func() and g_option_context_set_translation_domain()).
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: summary
parameter.parameter_description: a string to be shown in `--help` output before the list of options, or %NULL

function.name: g_option_context_set_translate_func
function.description:
Sets the function which is used to translate the contexts user-visible strings, for `--help` output. If @func is %NULL, strings are not translated.
Note that option groups have their own translation functions, this function only affects the @parameter_string (see g_option_context_new()), the summary (see g_option_context_set_summary()) and the description (see g_option_context_set_description()).
If you are using gettext(), you only need to set the translation domain, see g_option_context_set_translation_domain().
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to @func, or %NULL

parameter.name: destroy_notify
parameter.parameter_description: a function which gets called to free @data, or %NULL

function.name: g_option_context_set_translation_domain
function.description:
A convenience function to use gettext() for translating user-visible strings.
Since: 2.12

function.name: g_option_group_add_entries
function.description:
Adds the options specified in @entries to @group.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_option_group_free
function.description:
Frees a #GOptionGroup. Note that you must not free groups which have been added to a #GOptionContext.
Since: 2.6
Deprecated: 2.44: Use g_option_group_unref() instead.

function.name: g_option_group_new

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name for the option group, this is used to provide help for the options in this group with `--help-`@name

parameter.name: description
parameter.parameter_description: a description for this group to be shown in `--help`. This string is translated using the translation domain or translation function of the group

parameter.name: help_description
parameter.parameter_description: a description for the `--help-`@name option. This string is translated using the translation domain or translation function of the group

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data that will be passed to the pre- and post-parse hooks, the error hook and to callbacks of %G_OPTION_ARG_CALLBACK options, or %NULL

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: a function that will be called to free @user_data, or %NULL

function.return: a newly created option group. It should be added to a #GOptionContext or freed with g_option_group_unref().

function.name: g_option_group_ref
function.description:
Increments the reference count of @group by one.
Since: 2.44
function.return: a #GOptionGroup

function.name: g_option_group_set_error_hook
function.description:
Associates a function with @group which will be called from g_option_context_parse() when an error occurs.
Note that the user data to be passed to @error_func can be specified when constructing the group with g_option_group_new().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: error_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call when an error occurs

function.name: g_option_group_set_parse_hooks
function.description:
Associates two functions with @group which will be called from g_option_context_parse() before the first option is parsed and after the last option has been parsed, respectively.
Note that the user data to be passed to @pre_parse_func and @post_parse_func can be specified when constructing the group with g_option_group_new().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: pre_parse_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call before parsing, or %NULL

parameter.name: post_parse_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call after parsing, or %NULL

function.name: g_option_group_set_translate_func
function.description:
Sets the function which is used to translate user-visible strings, for `--help` output. Different groups can use different #GTranslateFuncs. If @func is %NULL, strings are not translated.
If you are using gettext(), you only need to set the translation domain, see g_option_group_set_translation_domain().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to @func, or %NULL

parameter.name: destroy_notify
parameter.parameter_description: a function which gets called to free @data, or %NULL

function.name: g_option_group_set_translation_domain
function.description:
A convenience function to use gettext() for translating user-visible strings.
Since: 2.6

function.name: g_option_group_unref
function.description:
Decrements the reference count of @group by one. If the reference count drops to 0, the @group will be freed. and all memory allocated by the @group is released.
Since: 2.44

function.name: g_param_spec_boolean
function.description:
Creates a new #GParamSpecBoolean instance specifying a %G_TYPE_BOOLEAN property. In many cases, it may be more appropriate to use an enum with g_param_spec_enum(), both to improve code clarity by using explicitly named values, and to allow for more values to be added in future without breaking API.
See g_param_spec_internal() for details on property names.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: canonical name of the property specified

parameter.name: nick
parameter.parameter_description: nick name for the property specified

parameter.name: default_value
parameter.parameter_description: default value for the property specified

function.return: a newly created parameter specification

parameter.parameter_description: a #GQuark, naming the user data pointer

function.return: the user data pointer set, or %NULL

function.name: g_param_spec_get_redirect_target
function.description:
If the paramspec redirects operations to another paramspec, returns that paramspec. Redirect is used typically for providing a new implementation of a property in a derived type while preserving all the properties from the parent type. Redirection is established by creating a property of type #GParamSpecOverride. See g_object_class_override_property() for an example of the use of this capability.
Since: 2.4
function.return: paramspec to which requests on this paramspec should be redirected, or %NULL if none.

function.name: g_param_spec_internal
function.description:
Creates a new #GParamSpec instance.
See [canonical parameter names][class@GObject.ParamSpec#parameter-names] for details of the rules for @name. Names which violate these rules lead to undefined behaviour.
Beyond the name, #GParamSpecs have two more descriptive strings, the @nick and @blurb, which may be used as a localized label and description. For GTK and related libraries these are considered deprecated and may be omitted, while for other libraries such as GStreamer and its plugins they are essential. When in doubt, follow the conventions used in the surrounding code and supporting libraries.

parameter.name: param_type
parameter.parameter_description: the #GType for the property; must be derived from %G_TYPE_PARAM

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the canonical name of the property

parameter.name: blurb
parameter.parameter_description: a short description of the property

function.return: a newly allocated #GParamSpec instance, which is initially floating

function.name: g_param_spec_is_valid_name
function.description:
Validate a property name for a #GParamSpec. This can be useful for dynamically-generated properties which need to be validated at run-time before actually trying to create them.
See [canonical parameter names][class@GObject.ParamSpec#parameter-names] for details of the rules for valid names.
Since: 2.66

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the canonical name of the property

function.return: %TRUE if @name is a valid property name, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_param_spec_long
function.description:
Creates a new #GParamSpecLong instance specifying a %G_TYPE_LONG property.
See g_param_spec_internal() for details on property names.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: canonical name of the property specified

parameter.name: nick
parameter.parameter_description: nick name for the property specified

parameter.name: minimum
parameter.parameter_description: minimum value for the property specified

parameter.name: maximum
parameter.parameter_description: maximum value for the property specified

parameter.name: default_value
parameter.parameter_description: default value for the property specified

function.return: a newly created parameter specification

parameter.name: nick

function.name: g_param_spec_override
function.description:
Creates a new property of type #GParamSpecOverride. This is used to direct operations to another paramspec, and will not be directly useful unless you are implementing a new base type similar to GObject.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: overridden
parameter.parameter_description: The property that is being overridden

function.return: the newly created #GParamSpec

function.description:
Creates a new #GParamSpecParam instance specifying a %G_TYPE_PARAM property.

See g_param_spec_internal() for details on property names.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: canonical name of the property specified

parameter.parameter_description: nick name for the property specified

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_free
function.description:
Frees the resources allocated by a #GParamSpecPool.
Since: 2.80

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_insert
function.description: Inserts a #GParamSpec in the pool.

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_list
function.description: Gets an array of all #GParamSpecs owned by @owner_type in the pool.

parameter.name: n_pspecs_p
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the length of the returned array

function.return: a newly allocated array containing pointers to all #GParamSpecs owned by @owner_type in the pool

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_list_owned
function.description: Gets an #GList of all #GParamSpecs owned by @owner_type in the pool.
function.return: a #GList of all #GParamSpecs owned by @owner_type in the pool#GParamSpecs.

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_lookup
function.description: Looks up a #GParamSpec in the pool.

parameter.name: walk_ancestors
parameter.parameter_description: If %TRUE, also try to find a #GParamSpec with @param_name owned by an ancestor of @owner_type.

function.return: The found #GParamSpec, or %NULL if no matching #GParamSpec was found.

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GParamSpecPool.
If @type_prefixing is %TRUE, lookups in the newly created pool will allow to specify the owner as a colon-separated prefix of the property name, like "GtkContainer:border-width". This feature is deprecated, so you should always set @type_prefixing to %FALSE.

parameter.name: type_prefixing
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the pool will support type-prefixed property names.

function.return: a newly allocated #GParamSpecPool.

function.name: g_param_spec_pool_remove
function.description: Removes a #GParamSpec from the pool.

function.name: g_param_spec_ref
function.description: Increments the reference count of @pspec.
function.return: the #GParamSpec that was passed into this function

function.name: g_param_spec_ref_sink
function.description:
Convenience function to ref and sink a #GParamSpec.
Since: 2.10
function.return: the #GParamSpec that was passed into this function

function.name: g_param_spec_set_qdata
function.description: Sets an opaque, named pointer on a #GParamSpec. The name is specified through a #GQuark (retrieved e.g. via g_quark_from_static_string()), and the pointer can be gotten back from the @pspec with g_param_spec_get_qdata(). Setting a previously set user data pointer, overrides (frees) the old pointer set, using %NULL as pointer essentially removes the data stored.

parameter.name: pspec
parameter.parameter_description: the #GParamSpec to set store a user data pointer

parameter.name: quark
parameter.parameter_description: a #GQuark, naming the user data pointer

function.name: g_param_spec_set_qdata_full
function.description: This function works like g_param_spec_set_qdata(), but in addition, a `void (*destroy) (gpointer)` function may be specified which is called with @data as argument when the @pspec is finalized, or the data is being overwritten by a call to g_param_spec_set_qdata() with the same @quark.

parameter.name: pspec
parameter.parameter_description: the #GParamSpec to set store a user data pointer

parameter.name: quark
parameter.parameter_description: a #GQuark, naming the user data pointer

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: function to invoke with @data as argument, when @data needs to be freed

function.name: g_param_spec_sink
function.description: The initial reference count of a newly created #GParamSpec is 1, even though no one has explicitly called g_param_spec_ref() on it yet. So the initial reference count is flagged as "floating", until someone calls `g_param_spec_ref (pspec); g_param_spec_sink (pspec);` in sequence on it, taking over the initial reference count (thus ending up with a @pspec that has a reference count of 1 still, but is not flagged "floating" anymore).

function.name: g_param_spec_steal_qdata
function.description: Gets back user data pointers stored via g_param_spec_set_qdata() and removes the @data from @pspec without invoking its destroy() function (if any was set). Usually, calling this function is only required to update user data pointers with a destroy notifier.

parameter.name: pspec
parameter.parameter_description: the #GParamSpec to get a stored user data pointer from

parameter.name: quark
parameter.parameter_description: a #GQuark, naming the user data pointer

function.return: the user data pointer set, or %NULL

function.name: g_param_type_register_static
function.description:
Registers @name as the name of a new static type derived from %G_TYPE_PARAM.
The type system uses the information contained in the #GParamSpecTypeInfo structure pointed to by @info to manage the #GParamSpec type and its instances.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: 0-terminated string used as the name of the new #GParamSpec type.

function.return: The new type identifier.

function.name: g_param_value_convert
function.description:
Transforms @src_value into @dest_value if possible, and then validates @dest_value, in order for it to conform to @pspec. If @strict_validation is %TRUE this function will only succeed if the transformed @dest_value complied to @pspec without modifications.
See also g_value_type_transformable(), g_value_transform() and g_param_value_validate().

parameter.name: strict_validation
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE requires @dest_value to conform to @pspec without modifications

function.return: %TRUE if transformation and validation were successful, %FALSE otherwise and @dest_value is left untouched.

function.name: g_param_value_defaults
function.description: Checks whether @value contains the default value as specified in @pspec.
function.return: whether @value contains the canonical default for this @pspec

function.name: g_param_value_is_valid
function.description:
Return whether the contents of @value comply with the specifications set out by @pspec.
Since: 2.74
function.return: whether the contents of @value comply with the specifications set out by @pspec.

function.name: g_param_value_set_default
function.description: Sets @value to its default value as specified in @pspec.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: a #GValue of correct type for @pspec; since 2.64, you can also pass an empty #GValue, initialized with %G_VALUE_INIT

function.name: g_param_value_validate
function.description: Ensures that the contents of @value comply with the specifications set out by @pspec. For example, a #GParamSpecInt might require that integers stored in @value may not be smaller than -42 and not be greater than +42. If @value contains an integer outside of this range, it is modified accordingly, so the resulting value will fit into the range -42 .. +42.
function.return: whether modifying @value was necessary to ensure validity

function.name: g_param_values_cmp
function.return: -1, 0 or +1, for a less than, equal to or greater than result

function.name: g_parse_debug_string
function.description:
Parses a string containing debugging options into a %guint containing bit flags. This is used within GDK and GTK to parse the debug options passed on the command line or through environment variables.
If @string is equal to "all", all flags are set. Any flags specified along with "all" in @string are inverted; thus, "all,foo,bar" or "foo,bar,all" sets all flags except those corresponding to "foo" and "bar".
If @string is equal to "help", all the available keys in @keys are printed out to standard error.

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: a list of debug options separated by colons, spaces, or commas, or %NULL.

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to an array of #GDebugKey which associate strings with bit flags.

parameter.name: nkeys
parameter.parameter_description: the number of #GDebugKeys in the array.

function.return: the combined set of bit flags.

function.name: g_path_buf_clear
function.description:
Clears the contents of the path buffer.
This function should be use to free the resources in a stack-allocated `GPathBuf` initialized using g_path_buf_init() or g_path_buf_init_from_path().
Since: 2.76

function.name: g_path_buf_clear_to_path
function.description:
Clears the contents of the path buffer and returns the built path.
This function returns `NULL` if the `GPathBuf` is empty.
See also: g_path_buf_to_path()
Since: 2.76
function.return: the built path

function.name: g_path_buf_copy
function.description:
Copies the contents of a path buffer into a new `GPathBuf`.
Since: 2.76
function.return: the newly allocated path buffer

function.name: g_path_buf_equal
function.description:
Compares two path buffers for equality and returns `TRUE` if they are equal.
The paths inside the path buffers are not going to be normalized, so `X/Y/Z/A/..`, `X/./Y/Z` and `X/Y/Z` are not going to be considered equal.
This function can be passed to g_hash_table_new() as the `key_equal_func` parameter.
Since: 2.76
function.return: `TRUE` if the two path buffers are equal, and `FALSE` otherwise

function.name: g_path_buf_free
function.description:
Frees a `GPathBuf` allocated by g_path_buf_new().
Since: 2.76

function.name: g_path_buf_free_to_path
function.description:
Frees a `GPathBuf` allocated by g_path_buf_new(), and returns the path inside the buffer.
This function returns `NULL` if the `GPathBuf` is empty.
See also: g_path_buf_to_path()
Since: 2.76
function.return: the path

function.name: g_path_buf_init
function.description:
Initializes a `GPathBuf` instance.
Since: 2.76
function.return: the initialized path builder

function.name: g_path_buf_init_from_path
function.description:
Initializes a `GPathBuf` instance with the given path.
Since: 2.76
function.return: the initialized path builder

function.name: g_path_buf_new
function.description:
Allocates a new `GPathBuf`.
Since: 2.76
function.return: the newly allocated path buffer

function.name: g_path_buf_new_from_path
function.description:
Allocates a new `GPathBuf` with the given @path.
Since: 2.76

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: the path used to initialize the buffer

function.return: the newly allocated path buffer

function.name: g_path_buf_pop
function.return: `TRUE` if the buffer was modified and `FALSE` otherwise

function.name: g_path_buf_push
function.return: the same pointer to @buf, for convenience

function.name: g_path_buf_set_extension
function.description:
Adds an extension to the file name in the path buffer.
If @extension is `NULL`, the extension will be unset.
If the path buffer does not have a file name set, this function returns `FALSE` and leaves the path buffer unmodified.
Since: 2.76
function.return: `TRUE` if the extension was replaced, and `FALSE` otherwise

function.name: g_path_buf_set_filename

parameter.name: file_name
parameter.parameter_description: the file name in the path

function.return: `TRUE` if the file name was replaced, and `FALSE` otherwise

function.name: g_path_buf_to_path
function.description:
Retrieves the built path from the path buffer.
On Windows, the result contains backslashes as directory separators, even if forward slashes were used in input.
If the path buffer is empty, this function returns `NULL`.
Since: 2.76
function.return: the path

function.name: g_path_get_basename
function.description:
Gets the last component of the filename.
If @file_name ends with a directory separator it gets the component before the last slash. If @file_name consists only of directory separators (and on Windows, possibly a drive letter), a single separator is returned. If @file_name is empty, it gets ".".
function.return: a newly allocated string containing the last component of the filename

function.name: g_path_get_dirname
function.description:
Gets the directory components of a file name. For example, the directory component of `/usr/bin/test` is `/usr/bin`. The directory component of `/` is `/`.
If the file name has no directory components "." is returned. The returned string should be freed when no longer needed.
function.return: the directory components of the file

function.name: g_path_is_absolute
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the given @file_name is an absolute file name. Note that this is a somewhat vague concept on Windows.
On POSIX systems, an absolute file name is well-defined. It always starts from the single root directory. For example "/usr/local".
On Windows, the concepts of current drive and drive-specific current directory introduce vagueness. This function interprets as an absolute file name one that either begins with a directory separator such as "\Users\tml" or begins with the root on a drive, for example "C:\Windows". The first case also includes UNC paths such as "\\\\myserver\docs\foo". In all cases, either slashes or backslashes are accepted.
Note that a file name relative to the current drive root does not truly specify a file uniquely over time and across processes, as the current drive is a per-process value and can be changed.
File names relative the current directory on some specific drive, such as "D:foo/bar", are not interpreted as absolute by this function, but they obviously are not relative to the normal current directory as returned by getcwd() or g_get_current_dir() either. Such paths should be avoided, or need to be handled using Windows-specific code.
function.return: %TRUE if @file_name is absolute

function.name: g_path_skip_root
function.description: Returns a pointer into @file_name after the root component, i.e. after the "/" in UNIX or "C:\" under Windows. If @file_name is not an absolute path it returns %NULL.
function.return: a pointer into @file_name after the root component

function.name: g_pattern_match
function.description:
Matches a string against a compiled pattern.
Passing the correct length of the string given is mandatory. The reversed string can be omitted by passing `NULL`, this is more efficient if the reversed version of the string to be matched is not at hand, as `g_pattern_match()` will only construct it if the compiled pattern requires reverse matches.
Note that, if the user code will (possibly) match a string against a multitude of patterns containing wildcards, chances are high that some patterns will require a reversed string. In this case, it’s more efficient to provide the reversed string to avoid multiple constructions thereof in the various calls to `g_pattern_match()`.
Note also that the reverse of a UTF-8 encoded string can in general not be obtained by [func@GLib.strreverse]. This works only if the string does not contain any multibyte characters. GLib offers the [func@GLib.utf8_strreverse] function to reverse UTF-8 encoded strings.
Deprecated: 2.70: Use [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match] instead

parameter.name: string_length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string (in bytes, i.e. `strlen()`, not [func@GLib.utf8_strlen])

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 encoded string to match

function.return: %TRUE if @string matches @pspec

function.name: g_pattern_match_simple
function.description:
Matches a string against a pattern given as a string.
If this function is to be called in a loop, it’s more efficient to compile the pattern once with [ctor@GLib.PatternSpec.new] and call [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match_string] repeatedly.

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 encoded string to match

function.return: %TRUE if @string matches @pspec

function.name: g_pattern_match_string
function.description:
Matches a string against a compiled pattern.
If the string is to be matched against more than one pattern, consider using [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match] instead while supplying the reversed string.
Deprecated: 2.70: Use [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match_string] instead

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 encoded string to match

function.return: %TRUE if @string matches @pspec

function.name: g_pattern_spec_copy
function.description:
Copies @pspec in a new [type@GLib.PatternSpec].
Since: 2.70
function.return: a copy of @pspec.

function.name: g_pattern_spec_equal
function.description: Compares two compiled pattern specs and returns whether they will match the same set of strings.
function.return: Whether the compiled patterns are equal

function.name: g_pattern_spec_free
function.description: Frees the memory allocated for the [type@GLib.PatternSpec].

function.name: g_pattern_spec_match
function.description:
Matches a string against a compiled pattern.
Passing the correct length of the string given is mandatory. The reversed string can be omitted by passing `NULL`, this is more efficient if the reversed version of the string to be matched is not at hand, as [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match] will only construct it if the compiled pattern requires reverse matches.
Note that, if the user code will (possibly) match a string against a multitude of patterns containing wildcards, chances are high that some patterns will require a reversed string. In this case, it’s more efficient to provide the reversed string to avoid multiple constructions thereof in the various calls to [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match].
Note also that the reverse of a UTF-8 encoded string can in general not be obtained by [func@GLib.strreverse]. This works only if the string does not contain any multibyte characters. GLib offers the [func@GLib.utf8_strreverse] function to reverse UTF-8 encoded strings.
Since: 2.70

parameter.name: string_length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string (in bytes, i.e. `strlen()`, not [func@GLib.utf8_strlen])

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 encoded string to match

function.return: %TRUE if @string matches @pspec

function.name: g_pattern_spec_match_string
function.description:
Matches a string against a compiled pattern.
If the string is to be matched against more than one pattern, consider using [method@GLib.PatternSpec.match] instead while supplying the reversed string.
Since: 2.70

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the UTF-8 encoded string to match

function.return: %TRUE if @string matches @pspec

function.name: g_pattern_spec_new
function.description: Compiles a pattern to a [type@GLib.PatternSpec].
function.return: a newly-allocated [type@GLib.PatternSpec]

function.name: g_pointer_bit_lock
function.description:
This is equivalent to g_bit_lock, but working on pointers (or other pointer-sized values).
For portability reasons, you may only lock on the bottom 32 bits of the pointer.
While @address has a `volatile` qualifier, this is a historical artifact and the argument passed to it should not be `volatile`.
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_pointer_bit_lock_and_get
function.description:
This is equivalent to g_bit_lock, but working on pointers (or other pointer-sized values).
For portability reasons, you may only lock on the bottom 32 bits of the pointer.
Since: 2.80

parameter.name: out_ptr
parameter.parameter_description: returns the set pointer atomically. This is the value after setting the lock, it thus always has the lock bit set, while previously @address had the lockbit unset. You may also use g_pointer_bit_lock_mask_ptr() to clear the lock bit.

function.name: g_pointer_bit_lock_mask_ptr
function.description:
This mangles @ptr as g_pointer_bit_lock() and g_pointer_bit_unlock() do.
Since: 2.80

parameter.name: lock_bit
parameter.parameter_description: the bit to set/clear. If set to `G_MAXUINT`, the lockbit is taken from @preserve_ptr or @ptr (depending on @preserve_mask).

parameter.name: set
parameter.parameter_description: whether to set (lock) the bit or unset (unlock). This has no effect, if @lock_bit is set to `G_MAXUINT`.

parameter.name: preserve_mask
parameter.parameter_description: if non-zero, a bit-mask for @preserve_ptr. The @preserve_mask bits from @preserve_ptr are set in the result. Note that the @lock_bit bit will be always set according to @set, regardless of @preserve_mask and @preserve_ptr (unless @lock_bit is `G_MAXUINT`).

parameter.name: preserve_ptr
parameter.parameter_description: if @preserve_mask is non-zero, the bits from this pointer are set in the result.

function.return: the mangled pointer.

function.name: g_pointer_bit_trylock
function.description:
This is equivalent to g_bit_trylock(), but working on pointers (or other pointer-sized values).
For portability reasons, you may only lock on the bottom 32 bits of the pointer.
While @address has a `volatile` qualifier, this is a historical artifact and the argument passed to it should not be `volatile`.
Since: 2.30
function.return: %TRUE if the lock was acquired

function.name: g_pointer_bit_unlock
function.description:
This is equivalent to g_bit_unlock, but working on pointers (or other pointer-sized values).
For portability reasons, you may only lock on the bottom 32 bits of the pointer.
While @address has a `volatile` qualifier, this is a historical artifact and the argument passed to it should not be `volatile`.
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_pointer_bit_unlock_and_set
function.description:
This is equivalent to g_pointer_bit_unlock() and atomically setting the pointer value.
Note that the lock bit will be cleared from the pointer. If the unlocked pointer that was set is not identical to @ptr, an assertion fails. In other words, @ptr must have @lock_bit unset. This also means, you usually can only use this on the lowest bits.
Since: 2.80

parameter.name: ptr
parameter.parameter_description: the new pointer value to set

parameter.name: preserve_mask
parameter.parameter_description: if non-zero, those bits of the current pointer in @address are preserved. Note that the @lock_bit bit will be always unset regardless of @ptr, @preserve_mask and the currently set value in @address.

function.name: g_pointer_type_register_static
function.description: Creates a new %G_TYPE_POINTER derived type id for a new pointer type with name @name.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the new pointer type.

function.return: a new %G_TYPE_POINTER derived type id for @name.

function.name: g_poll
function.description:
Polls @fds, as with the poll() system call, but portably. (On systems that don't have poll(), it is emulated using select().) This is used internally by #GMainContext, but it can be called directly if you need to block until a file descriptor is ready, but don't want to run the full main loop.
Each element of @fds is a #GPollFD describing a single file descriptor to poll. The @fd field indicates the file descriptor, and the @events field indicates the events to poll for. On return, the @revents fields will be filled with the events that actually occurred.
On POSIX systems, the file descriptors in @fds can be any sort of file descriptor, but the situation is much more complicated on Windows. If you need to use g_poll() in code that has to run on Windows, the easiest solution is to construct all of your #GPollFDs with g_io_channel_win32_make_pollfd().
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: nfds
parameter.parameter_description: the number of file descriptors in @fds

parameter.name: timeout
parameter.parameter_description: amount of time to wait, in milliseconds, or -1 to wait forever

function.return: the number of entries in @fds whose @revents fields were filled in, or 0 if the operation timed out, or -1 on error or if the call was interrupted.

function.name: g_prefix_error
function.description:
Formats a string according to @format and prefix it to an existing error message. If @err is %NULL (ie: no error variable) then do nothing.
If `*err` is %NULL (ie: an error variable is present but there is no error condition) then also do nothing.
Since: 2.16

function.name: g_prefix_error_literal
function.description:
Prefixes @prefix to an existing error message. If @err or `*err` is %NULL (i.e.: no error variable) then do nothing.
Since: 2.70

parameter.name: err
parameter.parameter_description: a return location for a #GError, or %NULL

function.name: g_print
function.description:
Outputs a formatted message via the print handler.
The default print handler outputs the encoded message to `stdout`, without appending a trailing new-line character. Typically, @format should end with its own new-line character.
This function should not be used from within libraries for debugging messages, since it may be redirected by applications to special purpose message windows or even files. Instead, libraries should use [func@GLib.log], [func@GLib.log_structured], or the convenience macros [func@GLib.message], [func@GLib.warning] and [func@GLib.error].

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the message format. See the `printf()` documentation

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to insert into the format string

function.name: g_printerr
function.description:
Outputs a formatted message via the error message handler.
The default handler outputs the encoded message to `stderr`, without appending a trailing new-line character. Typically, @format should end with its own new-line character.
This function should not be used from within libraries. Instead [func@GLib.log] or [func@GLib.log_structured] should be used, or the convenience macros [func@GLib.message], [func@GLib.warning] and [func@GLib.error].

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the message format. See the `printf()` documentation

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to insert into the format string

function.name: g_printf
function.description:
An implementation of the standard `printf()` function which supports positional parameters, as specified in the Single Unix Specification.
As with the standard `printf()`, this does not automatically append a trailing new-line character to the message, so typically @format should end with its own new-line character.
`glib/gprintf.h` must be explicitly included in order to use this function.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: a standard `printf()` format string, but notice [string precision pitfalls](string-utils.html#string-precision-pitfalls)

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the arguments to insert in the output

function.return: the number of bytes printed

function.name: g_printf_string_upper_bound
function.description:
Calculates the maximum space needed to store the output of the `sprintf()` function.
If @format or @args are invalid, `0` is returned. This could happen if, for example, @format contains an `%lc` or `%ls` placeholder and @args contains a wide character which cannot be represented in multibyte encoding. `0` can also be returned legitimately if, for example, @format is `%s` and @args is an empty string. The caller is responsible for differentiating these two return cases if necessary. It is recommended to not use `%lc` or `%ls` placeholders in any case, as their behaviour is locale-dependent.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the format string. See the `printf()` documentation

parameter.name: args
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to be inserted into the format string

function.return: the maximum space needed to store the formatted string, or `0` on error

function.name: g_private_get
function.description:
Returns the current value of the thread local variable @key.
If the value has not yet been set in this thread, %NULL is returned. Values are never copied between threads (when a new thread is created, for example).
function.return: the thread-local value

function.name: g_private_replace
function.description:
Sets the thread local variable @key to have the value @value in the current thread.
This function differs from g_private_set() in the following way: if the previous value was non-%NULL then the #GDestroyNotify handler for @key is run on it.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_private_set
function.description:
Sets the thread local variable @key to have the value @value in the current thread.
This function differs from g_private_replace() in the following way: the #GDestroyNotify for @key is not called on the old value.

function.name: g_propagate_error

parameter.name: src
parameter.parameter_description: error to move into the return location

function.name: g_propagate_prefixed_error
function.description:
If @dest is %NULL, free @src; otherwise, moves @src into `*dest`. `*dest` must be %NULL. After the move, add a prefix as with g_prefix_error().
Since: 2.16

parameter.name: src
parameter.parameter_description: error to move into the return location

function.name: g_ptr_array_add
function.description: Adds a pointer to the end of the pointer array. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.

function.name: g_ptr_array_copy
function.description:
Makes a full (deep) copy of a `GPtrArray`.
@func, as a [callback@GLib.CopyFunc], takes two arguments, the data to be copied and a @user_data pointer. On common processor architectures, it’s safe to pass `NULL` as @user_data if the copy function takes only one argument. You may get compiler warnings from this though if compiling with GCC’s `-Wcast-function-type` warning.
If @func is `NULL`, then only the pointers (and not what they are pointing to) are copied to the new `GPtrArray`.
The copy of @array will have the same [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] for its elements as @array. The copy will also be `NULL` terminated if (and only if) the source array is.
Since: 2.62

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a copy function used to copy every element in the array

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data passed to the copy function @func

function.return: The deep copy of the initial `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_extend
function.description:
Adds all pointers of @array to the end of the array @array_to_extend. The array will grow in size automatically if needed. @array_to_extend is modified in-place.
@func, as a [callback@GLib.CopyFunc], takes two arguments, the data to be copied and a @user_data pointer. On common processor architectures, it’s safe to pass `NULL` as @user_data if the copy function takes only one argument. You may get compiler warnings from this though if compiling with GCC’s `-Wcast-function-type` warning.
If @func is `NULL`, then only the pointers (and not what they are pointing to) are copied to the new `GPtrArray`.
Whether @array_to_extend is `NULL` terminated stays unchanged by this function.
Since: 2.62

parameter.name: array
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer array to add to the end of @array_to_extend

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a copy function used to copy every element in the array

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data passed to the copy function @func

function.name: g_ptr_array_extend_and_steal
function.description:
Adds all the pointers in @array to the end of @array_to_extend, transferring ownership of each element from @array to @array_to_extend and modifying @array_to_extend in-place. @array is then freed.
As with [func@GLib.PtrArray.free], @array will be destroyed if its reference count is 1. If its reference count is higher, it will be decremented and the length of @array set to zero.
Since: 2.62

parameter.name: array
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer array to add to the end of @array_to_extend

function.name: g_ptr_array_find
function.description:
Checks whether @needle exists in @haystack. If the element is found, true is returned and the element’s index is returned in @index_ (if non-`NULL`). Otherwise, false is returned and @index_ is undefined. If @needle exists multiple times in @haystack, the index of the first instance is returned.
This does pointer comparisons only. If you want to use more complex equality checks, such as string comparisons, use [func@GLib.PtrArray.find_with_equal_func].
Since: 2.54

parameter.name: haystack
parameter.parameter_description: the pointer array to be searched

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the return location for the index of the element, if found

function.return: true if @needle is one of the elements of @haystack; false otherwise

function.name: g_ptr_array_find_with_equal_func

parameter.name: haystack
parameter.parameter_description: the pointer array to be searched

parameter.name: equal_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element, which should return true when the desired element is found; or `NULL` to use pointer equality

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the return location for the index of the element, if found

function.return: true if @needle is one of the elements of @haystack; false otherwise

function.name: g_ptr_array_foreach
function.description:
Calls a function for each element of a `GPtrArray`. @func must not add elements to or remove elements from the array.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each array element

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data to pass to the function

function.name: g_ptr_array_free
function.description:
Frees the memory allocated for the `GPtrArray`. If @free_segment is true it frees the memory block holding the elements as well. Pass false if you want to free the `GPtrArray` wrapper but preserve the underlying array for use elsewhere. If the reference count of @array is greater than one, the `GPtrArray` wrapper is preserved but the size of @array will be set to zero.
If array contents point to dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed separately if @free_segment is true and no [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function has been set for @array.
Note that if the array is `NULL` terminated and @free_segment is false then this will always return an allocated `NULL` terminated buffer. If `pdata` is previously `NULL`, a new buffer will be allocated.
This function is not thread-safe. If using a `GPtrArray` from multiple threads, use only the atomic [func@GLib.PtrArray.ref] and [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref] functions.

parameter.name: free_segment
parameter.parameter_description: if true, the actual pointer array is freed as well

function.return: The allocated pointer array if @free_segment is false, otherwise `NULL`.

function.name: g_ptr_array_index
function.description:
Returns the pointer at the given index of the pointer array.
This does not perform bounds checking on the given @index_, so you are responsible for checking it against the array length.

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to return

function.return: The pointer at the given index

function.name: g_ptr_array_insert
function.description:
Inserts an element into the pointer array at the given index. The array will grow in size automatically if necessary.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index to place the new element at, or -1 to append

function.name: g_ptr_array_is_null_terminated
function.description:
Checks whether the @array was constructed as `NULL`-terminated.
This will only return true for arrays constructed by passing true to the `null_terminated` argument of [func@GLib.PtrArray.new_null_terminated]. It will not return true for normal arrays which have had a `NULL` element appended to them.
Since: 2.74
function.return: true if the array is made to be `NULL` terminated; false otherwise

function.name: g_ptr_array_new
function.description: Creates a new `GPtrArray` with a reference count of 1.
function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_from_array
function.description:
Creates a new `GPtrArray`, copying @len pointers from @data, and setting the array’s reference count to 1.
This avoids having to manually add each element one by one.
If @copy_func is provided, then it is used to copy each element before adding them to the new array. If it is `NULL` then the pointers are copied directly.
It also sets @element_free_func for freeing each element when the array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Do not use it if @len is greater than [`G_MAXUINT`](types.html#guint). `GPtrArray` stores the length of its data in `guint`, which may be shorter than `gsize`.
Since: 2.76

parameter.name: copy_func
parameter.parameter_description: a copy function used to copy every element in the array

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements on @array destruction

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_from_null_terminated_array
function.description:
Creates a new `GPtrArray` copying the pointers from @data after having computed the length of it and with a reference count of 1. This avoids having to manually add each element one by one. If @copy_func is provided, then it is used to copy the data in the new array. It also sets @element_free_func for freeing each element when the array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Do not use it if the @data has more than [`G_MAXUINT`](types.html#guint) elements. `GPtrArray` stores the length of its data in `guint`, which may be shorter than `gsize`.
Since: 2.76

parameter.name: copy_func
parameter.parameter_description: a copy function used to copy every element in the array

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements on @array destruction

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_full
function.description:
Creates a new `GPtrArray` with @reserved_size pointers preallocated and a reference count of 1. This avoids frequent reallocation, if you are going to add many pointers to the array. Note however that the size of the array is still 0. It also sets @element_free_func for freeing each element when the array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements with destroy @array

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_null_terminated
function.description:
Like [func@GLib.PtrArray.new_full] but also allows to set the array to be `NULL` terminated. A `NULL` terminated pointer array has an additional `NULL` pointer after the last element, beyond the current length.
`GPtrArray` created by other constructors are not automatically `NULL` terminated.
Note that if the @array’s length is zero and currently no data array is allocated, then `pdata` will still be `NULL`. `GPtrArray` will only `NULL` terminate `pdata`, if an actual array is allocated. It does not guarantee that an array is always allocated. In other words, if the length is zero, then `pdata` may either point to a `NULL` terminated array of length zero or be `NULL`.
Since: 2.74

parameter.name: reserved_size
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pointers preallocated. If @null_terminated is `TRUE`, the actually allocated buffer size is @reserved_size plus 1, unless @reserved_size is zero, in which case no initial buffer gets allocated.

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements during destruction of @array

parameter.name: null_terminated
parameter.parameter_description: if true, make the array `NULL` terminated

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_take
function.description:
Creates a new `GPtrArray` with @data as pointers, @len as length and a reference count of 1.
This avoids having to copy such data manually. After this call, @data belongs to the `GPtrArray` and may no longer be modified by the caller. The memory of @data has to be dynamically allocated and will eventually be freed with [func@GLib.free].
It also sets @element_free_func for freeing each element when the array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Do not use it if @len is greater than [`G_MAXUINT`](types.html#guint). `GPtrArray` stores the length of its data in `guint`, which may be shorter than `gsize`.
Since: 2.76

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements on @array destruction

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_take_null_terminated
function.description:
Creates a new `GPtrArray` with @data as pointers, computing the length of it and setting the reference count to 1.
This avoids having to copy such data manually. After this call, @data belongs to the `GPtrArray` and may no longer be modified by the caller. The memory of @data has to be dynamically allocated and will eventually be freed with [func@GLib.free].
The length is calculated by iterating through @data until the first `NULL` element is found.
It also sets @element_free_func for freeing each element when the array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Do not use it if the @data length is greater than [`G_MAXUINT`](types.html#guint). `GPtrArray` stores the length of its data in `guint`, which may be shorter than `gsize`.
Since: 2.76

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements on @array destruction

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_new_with_free_func
function.description:
Creates a new `GPtrArray` with a reference count of 1 and use @element_free_func for freeing each element when the array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements with destroy @array

function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_ref
function.description:
Atomically increments the reference count of @array by one. This function is thread-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22
function.return: The passed in `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove
function.description:
Removes the first occurrence of the given pointer from the pointer array. The following elements are moved down one place. If @array has a non-`NULL` [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function it is called for the removed element.
It returns true if the pointer was removed, or false if the pointer was not found.
function.return: true if the pointer is found and removed; false otherwise

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_fast
function.description:
Removes the first occurrence of the given pointer from the pointer array. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the array. But it is faster than [func@GLib.PtrArray.remove]. If @array has a non-`NULL` [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function it is called for the removed element.
It returns true if the pointer was removed, or false if the pointer was not found.
function.return: true if the pointer is found and removed; false otherwise

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_index
function.description: Removes the pointer at the given index from the pointer array. The following elements are moved down one place. If @array has a non-`NULL` [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function it is called for the removed element. If so, the return value from this function will potentially point to freed memory (depending on the [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] implementation).

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to remove

function.return: The pointer which was removed

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_index_fast
function.description: Removes the pointer at the given index from the pointer array. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the array. But it is faster than [func@GLib.PtrArray.remove_index]. If @array has a non-`NULL` [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function it is called for the removed element. If so, the return value from this function will potentially point to freed memory (depending on the [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] implementation).

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to remove

function.return: The pointer which was removed

function.name: g_ptr_array_remove_range
function.description:
Removes the given number of pointers starting at the given index from a `GPtrArray`. The following elements are moved to close the gap. If @array has a non-`NULL` [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function it is called for the removed elements.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the first pointer to remove

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the number of pointers to remove

function.return: The @array

function.name: g_ptr_array_set_free_func
function.description:
Sets a function for freeing each element when @array is destroyed either via [func@GLib.PtrArray.unref], when [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] is called with @free_segment set to true or when removing elements.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: element_free_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to free elements during destruction of @array

function.name: g_ptr_array_set_size
function.description: Sets the size of the array. When making the array larger, newly-added elements will be set to `NULL`. When making it smaller, if @array has a non-`NULL` [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] function then it will be called for the removed elements.

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the new length of the pointer array

function.name: g_ptr_array_sized_new
function.description: Creates a new `GPtrArray` with @reserved_size pointers preallocated and a reference count of 1. This avoids frequent reallocation, if you are going to add many pointers to the array. Note however that the size of the array is still 0.
function.return: The new `GPtrArray`

function.name: g_ptr_array_sort
g_ptr_array_sort_values
function.description:
Sorts the array, using @compare_func which should be a `qsort()`-style comparison function (returns less than zero for first arg is less than second arg, zero for equal, greater than zero if first arg is greater than second arg).
This is guaranteed to be a stable sort.
Since: 2.76

function.name: g_ptr_array_sort_values_with_data
function.description:
Like [func@GLib.PtrArray.sort_values], but the comparison function has an extra user data argument.
This is guaranteed to be a stable sort.
Since: 2.76

function.name: g_ptr_array_sort_with_data
g_ptr_array_steal

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to retrieve the number of elements of the original array

function.return: The allocated element data. This may be `NULL`if the array doesn’t have any elements (i.e. if `*len` is zero).

function.name: g_ptr_array_steal_index
function.description:
Removes the pointer at the given index from the pointer array. The following elements are moved down one place. The [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] for @array is *not* called on the removed element; ownership is transferred to the caller of this function.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to steal

function.return: The pointer which was removed

function.name: g_ptr_array_steal_index_fast
function.description:
Removes the pointer at the given index from the pointer array. The last element in the array is used to fill in the space, so this function does not preserve the order of the array. But it is faster than [func@GLib.PtrArray.steal_index]. The [callback@GLib.DestroyNotify] for @array is *not* called on the removed element; ownership is transferred to the caller of this function.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: index_
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the pointer to steal

function.return: The pointer which was removed

function.name: g_ptr_array_unref
function.description:
Atomically decrements the reference count of @array by one. If the reference count drops to 0, the effect is the same as calling [func@GLib.PtrArray.free] with @free_segment set to true. This function is thread-safe and may be called from any thread.
Since: 2.22

function.name: g_qsort_with_data
function.description:
This is just like the standard C [`qsort()`](man:qsort(3)) function, but the comparison routine accepts a user data argument (like [`qsort_r()`](man:qsort_r(3))).
Unlike `qsort()`, this is guaranteed to be a stable sort (since GLib 2.32).
Deprecated: 2.82: `total_elems` is too small to represent larger arrays; use [func@GLib.sort_array] instead

function.name: g_quark_from_static_string
function.description:
Gets the #GQuark identifying the given (static) string. If the string does not currently have an associated #GQuark, a new #GQuark is created, linked to the given string.
Note that this function is identical to g_quark_from_string() except that if a new #GQuark is created the string itself is used rather than a copy. This saves memory, but can only be used if the string will continue to exist until the program terminates. It can be used with statically allocated strings in the main program, but not with statically allocated memory in dynamically loaded modules, if you expect to ever unload the module again (e.g. do not use this function in GTK theme engines).
This function must not be used before library constructors have finished running. In particular, this means it cannot be used to initialize global variables in C++.
function.return: the #GQuark identifying the string, or 0 if @string is %NULL

function.name: g_quark_from_string
function.description:
Gets the #GQuark identifying the given string. If the string does not currently have an associated #GQuark, a new #GQuark is created, using a copy of the string.
This function must not be used before library constructors have finished running. In particular, this means it cannot be used to initialize global variables in C++.
function.return: the #GQuark identifying the string, or 0 if @string is %NULL

function.name: g_quark_to_string
function.description: Gets the string associated with the given #GQuark.
function.return: the string associated with the #GQuark

function.name: g_quark_try_string
function.description:
Gets the #GQuark associated with the given string, or 0 if string is %NULL or it has no associated #GQuark.
If you want the GQuark to be created if it doesn't already exist, use g_quark_from_string() or g_quark_from_static_string().
This function must not be used before library constructors have finished running.
function.return: the #GQuark associated with the string, or 0 if @string is %NULL or there is no #GQuark associated with it

function.name: g_queue_clear
function.description:
Removes all the elements in @queue. If queue elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed first.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_queue_clear_full
function.description:
Convenience method, which frees all the memory used by a #GQueue, and calls the provided @free_func on each item in the #GQueue.
Since: 2.60

parameter.name: free_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to be called to free memory allocated

function.name: g_queue_copy
function.description:
Copies a @queue. Note that is a shallow copy. If the elements in the queue consist of pointers to data, the pointers are copied, but the actual data is not.
Since: 2.4
function.return: a copy of @queue

function.name: g_queue_delete_link

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that must be part of @queue

function.name: g_queue_find
function.description:
Finds the first link in @queue which contains @data.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the first link in @queue which contains @data

function.name: g_queue_find_custom
function.description:
Finds an element in a #GQueue, using a supplied function to find the desired element. It iterates over the queue, calling the given function which should return 0 when the desired element is found. The function takes two gconstpointer arguments, the #GQueue element's data as the first argument and the given user data as the second argument.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: a #GCompareFunc to call for each element. It should return 0 when the desired element is found

function.return: the found link, or %NULL if it wasn't found

function.name: g_queue_foreach
function.description:
Calls @func for each element in the queue passing @user_data to the function.
It is safe for @func to remove the element from @queue, but it must not modify any part of the queue after that element.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each element's data

function.name: g_queue_free
function.description:
Frees the memory allocated for the #GQueue. Only call this function if @queue was created with g_queue_new(). If queue elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, they should be freed first.
If queue elements contain dynamically-allocated memory, you should either use g_queue_free_full() or free them manually first.

function.name: g_queue_free_full

parameter.name: free_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to be called to free each element's data

function.name: g_queue_get_length
function.description:
Returns the number of items in @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the number of items in @queue

function.name: g_queue_index
function.description:
Returns the position of the first element in @queue which contains @data.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the position of the first element in @queue which contains @data, or -1 if no element in @queue contains @data

function.name: g_queue_init
function.description:
A statically-allocated #GQueue must be initialized with this function before it can be used. Alternatively you can initialize it with %G_QUEUE_INIT. It is not necessary to initialize queues created with g_queue_new().
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_queue_insert_after

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that must be part of @queue, or %NULL to push at the head of the queue.

function.name: g_queue_insert_after_link

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that must be part of @queue, or %NULL to push at the head of the queue.

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link to insert which must not be part of any other list.

function.name: g_queue_insert_before

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that must be part of @queue, or %NULL to push at the tail of the queue.

function.name: g_queue_insert_before_link

parameter.name: sibling
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that must be part of @queue, or %NULL to push at the tail of the queue.

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link to insert which must not be part of any other list.

function.name: g_queue_insert_sorted
function.description:
Inserts @data into @queue using @func to determine the new position.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to compare elements in the queue. It is called with two elements of the @queue and @user_data. It should return 0 if the elements are equal, a negative value if the first element comes before the second, and a positive value if the second element comes before the first.

function.name: g_queue_is_empty
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the queue is empty.
function.return: %TRUE if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_link_index
function.description:
Returns the position of @link_ in @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the position of @link_, or -1 if the link is not part of @queue

function.name: g_queue_new
function.description: Creates a new #GQueue.
function.return: a newly allocated #GQueue

function.name: g_queue_peek_head
function.description: Returns the first element of the queue.
function.return: the data of the first element in the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_peek_head_link
function.description:
Returns the first link in @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the first link in @queue, or %NULL if @queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_peek_nth
function.description:
Returns the @n'th element of @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the data for the @n'th element of @queue, or %NULL if @n is off the end of @queue

function.name: g_queue_peek_nth_link
function.description:
Returns the link at the given position
Since: 2.4
function.return: the link at the @n'th position, or %NULL if @n is off the end of the list

function.name: g_queue_peek_tail
function.description: Returns the last element of the queue.
function.return: the data of the last element in the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_peek_tail_link
function.description:
Returns the last link in @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the last link in @queue, or %NULL if @queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_pop_head
function.description: Removes the first element of the queue and returns its data.
function.return: the data of the first element in the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_pop_head_link
function.description: Removes and returns the first element of the queue.
function.return: the #GList element at the head of the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_pop_nth
function.description:
Removes the @n'th element of @queue and returns its data.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the element's data, or %NULL if @n is off the end of @queue

function.name: g_queue_pop_nth_link
function.description:
Removes and returns the link at the given position.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the @n'th link, or %NULL if @n is off the end of @queue

function.name: g_queue_pop_tail
function.description: Removes the last element of the queue and returns its data.
function.return: the data of the last element in the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_pop_tail_link
function.description: Removes and returns the last element of the queue.
function.return: the #GList element at the tail of the queue, or %NULL if the queue is empty

function.name: g_queue_push_head
function.description: Adds a new element at the head of the queue.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element.

function.name: g_queue_push_head_link
function.description: Adds a new element at the head of the queue.

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a single #GList element, not a list with more than one element

function.name: g_queue_push_nth
function.description:
Inserts a new element into @queue at the given position.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

parameter.name: n
parameter.parameter_description: the position to insert the new element. If @n is negative or larger than the number of elements in the @queue, the element is added to the end of the queue.

function.name: g_queue_push_nth_link
function.description:
Inserts @link into @queue at the given position.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: n

function.name: g_queue_push_tail
function.description: Adds a new element at the tail of the queue.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new element

function.name: g_queue_push_tail_link
function.description: Adds a new element at the tail of the queue.

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a single #GList element, not a list with more than one element

function.name: g_queue_remove
function.description:
Removes the first element in @queue that contains @data.
Since: 2.4
function.return: %TRUE if @data was found and removed from @queue

function.name: g_queue_remove_all
function.description:
Remove all elements whose data equals @data from @queue.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the number of elements removed from @queue

function.name: g_queue_reverse
function.description:
Reverses the order of the items in @queue.
Since: 2.4

function.name: g_queue_sort
function.description:
Sorts @queue using @compare_func.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: compare_func
parameter.parameter_description: the #GCompareDataFunc used to sort @queue. This function is passed two elements of the queue and should return 0 if they are equal, a negative value if the first comes before the second, and a positive value if the second comes before the first.

function.name: g_queue_unlink

parameter.name: link_
parameter.parameter_description: a #GList link that must be part of @queue

function.name: g_rand_boolean
function.description: Returns a random #gboolean from @rand_. This corresponds to an unbiased coin toss.
function.return: a random #gboolean

function.name: g_rand_copy
function.description:
Copies a #GRand into a new one with the same exact state as before. This way you can take a snapshot of the random number generator for replaying later.
Since: 2.4
function.return: the new #GRand

function.name: g_rand_double
function.description: Returns the next random #gdouble from @rand_ equally distributed over the range [0..1).
function.return: a random number

function.name: g_rand_double_range
function.description: Returns the next random #gdouble from @rand_ equally distributed over the range [@begin..@end).

parameter.name: begin
parameter.parameter_description: lower closed bound of the interval

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: upper open bound of the interval

function.return: a random number

function.name: g_rand_free
function.description: Frees the memory allocated for the #GRand.

function.name: g_rand_int
function.description: Returns the next random #guint32 from @rand_ equally distributed over the range [0..2^32-1].
function.return: a random number

function.name: g_rand_int_range
function.description: Returns the next random #gint32 from @rand_ equally distributed over the range [@begin..@end-1].

parameter.name: begin
parameter.parameter_description: lower closed bound of the interval

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: upper open bound of the interval

function.return: a random number

function.name: g_rand_new
function.description:
Creates a new random number generator initialized with a seed taken either from `/dev/urandom` (if existing) or from the current time (as a fallback).
On Windows, the seed is taken from rand_s().
function.return: the new #GRand

function.name: g_rand_new_with_seed
function.description: Creates a new random number generator initialized with @seed.

parameter.name: seed
parameter.parameter_description: a value to initialize the random number generator

function.return: the new #GRand

function.name: g_rand_new_with_seed_array
function.description:
Creates a new random number generator initialized with @seed.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: seed
parameter.parameter_description: an array of seeds to initialize the random number generator

parameter.name: seed_length
parameter.parameter_description: an array of seeds to initialize the random number generator

function.return: the new #GRand

function.name: g_rand_set_seed
function.description: Sets the seed for the random number generator #GRand to @seed.

parameter.name: seed
parameter.parameter_description: a value to reinitialize the random number generator

function.name: g_rand_set_seed_array
function.description:
Initializes the random number generator by an array of longs. Array can be of arbitrary size, though only the first 624 values are taken. This function is useful if you have many low entropy seeds, or if you require more then 32 bits of actual entropy for your application.
Since: 2.4

function.name: g_random_boolean
function.description: Returns a random #gboolean. This corresponds to an unbiased coin toss.
function.return: a random #gboolean

function.name: g_random_double
function.description: Returns a random #gdouble equally distributed over the range [0..1).
function.return: a random number
