function.name: g_random_double_range
function.description: Returns a random #gdouble equally distributed over the range [@begin..@end).

parameter.name: begin
parameter.parameter_description: lower closed bound of the interval

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: upper open bound of the interval

function.return: a random number

function.name: g_random_int
function.description: Return a random #guint32 equally distributed over the range [0..2^32-1].
function.return: a random number

function.name: g_random_int_range
function.description: Returns a random #gint32 equally distributed over the range [@begin..@end-1].

parameter.name: begin
parameter.parameter_description: lower closed bound of the interval

parameter.name: end
parameter.parameter_description: upper open bound of the interval

function.return: a random number

function.name: g_random_set_seed
function.description: Sets the seed for the global random number generator, which is used by the g_random_* functions, to @seed.

parameter.name: seed
parameter.parameter_description: a value to reinitialize the global random number generator

function.name: g_rc_box_acquire
function.description:
Acquires a reference on the data pointed by @mem_block.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: mem_block
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to reference counted data

function.return: a pointer to the data, with its reference count increased

function.name: g_rc_box_alloc
function.description:
Allocates @block_size bytes of memory, and adds reference counting semantics to it.
The data will be freed when its reference count drops to zero.
The allocated data is guaranteed to be suitably aligned for any built-in type.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: block_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the allocation, must be greater than 0

function.return: a pointer to the allocated memory

function.name: g_rc_box_alloc0
function.description:
Allocates @block_size bytes of memory, and adds reference counting semantics to it.
The contents of the returned data is set to zero.
The data will be freed when its reference count drops to zero.
The allocated data is guaranteed to be suitably aligned for any built-in type.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: block_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of the allocation, must be greater than 0

function.return: a pointer to the allocated memory

function.name: g_rc_box_dup
function.description:
Allocates a new block of data with reference counting semantics, and copies @block_size bytes of @mem_block into it.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: block_size
parameter.parameter_description: the number of bytes to copy, must be greater than 0

function.return: a pointer to the allocated memory

function.name: g_rc_box_get_size
function.description:
Retrieves the size of the reference counted data pointed by @mem_block.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: mem_block
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to reference counted data

function.return: the size of the data, in bytes

function.name: g_rc_box_new
function.description:
A convenience macro to allocate reference counted data with the size of the given @type.
This macro calls g_rc_box_alloc() with `sizeof (@type)` and casts the returned pointer to a pointer of the given @type, avoiding a type cast in the source code.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the type to allocate, typically a structure name

function.return: a pointer to the allocated memory, cast to a pointer for the given @type

function.name: g_rc_box_new0
function.description:
A convenience macro to allocate reference counted data with the size of the given @type, and set its contents to zero.
This macro calls g_rc_box_alloc0() with `sizeof (@type)` and casts the returned pointer to a pointer of the given @type, avoiding a type cast in the source code.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the type to allocate, typically a structure name

function.return: a pointer to the allocated memory, cast to a pointer for the given @type

function.name: g_rc_box_release
function.description:
Releases a reference on the data pointed by @mem_block.
If the reference was the last one, it will free the resources allocated for @mem_block.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: mem_block
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to reference counted data

function.name: g_rc_box_release_full
function.description:
Releases a reference on the data pointed by @mem_block.
If the reference was the last one, it will call @clear_func to clear the contents of @mem_block, and then will free the resources allocated for @mem_block.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: mem_block
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to reference counted data

parameter.name: clear_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call when clearing the data

function.name: g_realloc
function.description:
Reallocates the memory pointed to by @mem, so that it now has space for @n_bytes bytes of memory. It returns the new address of the memory, which may have been moved. @mem may be %NULL, in which case it's considered to have zero-length. @n_bytes may be 0, in which case %NULL will be returned and @mem will be freed unless it is %NULL.
If the allocation fails (because the system is out of memory), the program is terminated.

parameter.name: n_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: new size of the memory in bytes

function.return: the new address of the allocated memory

function.name: g_realloc_n
function.description:
This function is similar to g_realloc(), allocating (@n_blocks * @n_block_bytes) bytes, but care is taken to detect possible overflow during multiplication.
If the allocation fails (because the system is out of memory), the program is terminated.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: n_blocks
parameter.parameter_description: the number of blocks to allocate

parameter.name: n_block_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: the size of each block in bytes

function.return: the new address of the allocated memory

function.name: g_rec_mutex_clear
function.description:
Frees the resources allocated to a recursive mutex with g_rec_mutex_init().
This function should not be used with a #GRecMutex that has been statically allocated.
Calling g_rec_mutex_clear() on a locked recursive mutex leads to undefined behaviour.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_rec_mutex_init
g_rec_mutex_lock
function.description:
Locks @rec_mutex. If @rec_mutex is already locked by another thread, the current thread will block until @rec_mutex is unlocked by the other thread. If @rec_mutex is already locked by the current thread, the 'lock count' of @rec_mutex is increased. The mutex will only become available again when it is unlocked as many times as it has been locked.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_rec_mutex_locker_free
function.description:
Unlock @locker's recursive mutex. See g_rec_mutex_locker_new() for details.
No memory is freed, it is equivalent to a g_rec_mutex_unlock() call.
Since: 2.60

function.name: g_rec_mutex_locker_new
function.return: a #GRecMutexLocker

function.name: g_rec_mutex_trylock
function.description:
Tries to lock @rec_mutex. If @rec_mutex is already locked by another thread, it immediately returns %FALSE. Otherwise it locks @rec_mutex and returns %TRUE.
Since: 2.32
function.return: %TRUE if @rec_mutex could be locked

function.name: g_rec_mutex_unlock
function.description:
Unlocks @rec_mutex. If another thread is blocked in a g_rec_mutex_lock() call for @rec_mutex, it will become unblocked and can lock @rec_mutex itself.
Calling g_rec_mutex_unlock() on a recursive mutex that is not locked by the current thread leads to undefined behaviour.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_ref_count_compare
function.description:
Compares the current value of @rc with @val.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: rc
parameter.parameter_description: the address of a reference count variable

function.return: %TRUE if the reference count is the same as the given value

function.name: g_ref_count_dec
function.description:
Decreases the reference count.
If %TRUE is returned, the reference count reached 0. After this point, @rc is an undefined state and must be reinitialized with g_ref_count_init() to be used again.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: rc
parameter.parameter_description: the address of a reference count variable

function.return: %TRUE if the reference count reached 0, and %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_ref_count_inc
function.description:
Increases the reference count.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: rc
parameter.parameter_description: the address of a reference count variable

function.name: g_ref_count_init
function.description:
Initializes a reference count variable to 1.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: rc
parameter.parameter_description: the address of a reference count variable

function.name: g_ref_string_acquire
function.description:
Acquires a reference on a string.
Since: 2.58
function.return: the given string, with its reference count increased

function.name: g_ref_string_equal
function.description:
Compares two ref-counted strings for byte-by-byte equality.
It can be passed to [func@GLib.HashTable.new] as the key equality function, and behaves exactly the same as [func@GLib.str_equal] (or `strcmp()`), but can return slightly faster as it can check the string lengths before checking all the bytes.
Since: 2.84
function.return: `TRUE` if the strings are equal, otherwise `FALSE`

function.name: g_ref_string_length
function.description:
Retrieves the length of @str.
Since: 2.58
function.return: the length of the given string, in bytes

function.name: g_ref_string_new
function.description:
Creates a new reference counted string and copies the contents of @str into it.
Since: 2.58
function.return: the newly created reference counted string

function.name: g_ref_string_new_intern
function.description:
Creates a new reference counted string and copies the content of @str into it.
If you call this function multiple times with the same @str, or with the same contents of @str, it will return a new reference, instead of creating a new string.
Since: 2.58
function.return: the newly created reference counted string, or a new reference to an existing string

function.name: g_ref_string_new_len
function.description:
Creates a new reference counted string and copies the contents of @str into it, up to @len bytes.
Since this function does not stop at nul bytes, it is the caller's responsibility to ensure that @str has at least @len addressable bytes.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: len
parameter.parameter_description: length of @str to use, or -1 if @str is nul-terminated

function.return: the newly created reference counted string

function.name: g_ref_string_release
function.description:
Releases a reference on a string; if it was the last reference, the resources allocated by the string are freed as well.
Since: 2.58

function.name: g_regex_check_replacement
function.description:
Checks whether @replacement is a valid replacement string (see g_regex_replace()), i.e. that all escape sequences in it are valid.
If @has_references is not %NULL then @replacement is checked for pattern references. For instance, replacement text 'foo\n' does not contain references and may be evaluated without information about actual match, but '\0\1' (whole match followed by first subpattern) requires valid #GMatchInfo object.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: has_references
parameter.parameter_description: location to store information about references in @replacement or %NULL

function.return: whether @replacement is a valid replacement string

function.name: g_regex_escape_nul
function.description:
Escapes the nul characters in @string to "\x00". It can be used to compile a regex with embedded nul characters.
For completeness, @length can be -1 for a nul-terminated string. In this case the output string will be of course equal to @string.
Since: 2.30
function.return: a newly-allocated escaped string

function.name: g_regex_escape_string

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

function.return: a newly-allocated escaped string

function.name: g_regex_get_capture_count
function.description:
Returns the number of capturing subpatterns in the pattern.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the number of capturing subpatterns

function.name: g_regex_get_compile_flags
function.description:
Returns the compile options that @regex was created with.
Depending on the version of PCRE that is used, this may or may not include flags set by option expressions such as `(?i)` found at the top-level within the compiled pattern.
Since: 2.26
function.return: flags from #GRegexCompileFlags

function.name: g_regex_get_has_cr_or_lf
function.description:
Checks whether the pattern contains explicit CR or LF references.
Since: 2.34
function.return: %TRUE if the pattern contains explicit CR or LF references

function.name: g_regex_get_match_flags
function.description:
Returns the match options that @regex was created with.
Since: 2.26
function.return: flags from #GRegexMatchFlags

function.name: g_regex_get_max_backref
function.description:
Returns the number of the highest back reference in the pattern, or 0 if the pattern does not contain back references.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the number of the highest back reference

function.name: g_regex_get_max_lookbehind
function.description:
Gets the number of characters in the longest lookbehind assertion in the pattern. This information is useful when doing multi-segment matching using the partial matching facilities.
Since: 2.38
function.return: the number of characters in the longest lookbehind assertion.

function.name: g_regex_get_pattern
function.description:
Gets the pattern string associated with @regex, i.e. a copy of the string passed to g_regex_new().
Since: 2.14
function.return: the pattern of @regex

function.name: g_regex_get_string_number
function.description:
Retrieves the number of the subexpression named @name.
Since: 2.14
function.return: The number of the subexpression or -1 if @name does not exists

function.name: g_regex_match

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_all
function.description:
Using the standard algorithm for regular expression matching only the longest match in the string is retrieved. This function uses a different algorithm so it can retrieve all the possible matches. For more documentation see g_regex_match_all_full().
A #GMatchInfo structure, used to get information on the match, is stored in @match_info if not %NULL. Note that if @match_info is not %NULL then it is created even if the function returns %FALSE, i.e. you must free it regardless if regular expression actually matched.
@string is not copied and is used in #GMatchInfo internally. If you use any #GMatchInfo method (except g_match_info_free()) after freeing or modifying @string then the behaviour is undefined.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_all_full
function.description:
Using the standard algorithm for regular expression matching only the longest match in the @string is retrieved, it is not possible to obtain all the available matches. For instance matching `"<a> <b> <c>"` against the pattern `"<.*>"` you get `"<a> <b> <c>"`.
This function uses a different algorithm (called DFA, i.e. deterministic finite automaton), so it can retrieve all the possible matches, all starting at the same point in the string. For instance matching `"<a> <b> <c>"` against the pattern `"<.*>"` you would obtain three matches: `"<a> <b> <c>"`, `"<a> <b>"` and `"<a>"`.
The number of matched strings is retrieved using g_match_info_get_match_count(). To obtain the matched strings and their position you can use, respectively, g_match_info_fetch() and g_match_info_fetch_pos(). Note that the strings are returned in reverse order of length; that is, the longest matching string is given first.
Note that the DFA algorithm is slower than the standard one and it is not able to capture substrings, so backreferences do not work.
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting %G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Unless %G_REGEX_RAW is specified in the options, @string must be valid UTF-8.
A #GMatchInfo structure, used to get information on the match, is stored in @match_info if not %NULL. Note that if @match_info is not %NULL then it is created even if the function returns %FALSE, i.e. you must free it regardless if regular expression actually matched.
@string is not copied and is used in #GMatchInfo internally. If you use any #GMatchInfo method (except g_match_info_free()) after freeing or modifying @string then the behaviour is undefined.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match, in bytes

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_full

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match, in bytes

parameter.name: match_info
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to location where to store the #GMatchInfo, or %NULL if you do not need it

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: %TRUE is the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_match_simple
function.description:
Scans for a match in @string for @pattern.
This function is equivalent to g_regex_match() but it does not require to compile the pattern with g_regex_new(), avoiding some lines of code when you need just to do a match without extracting substrings, capture counts, and so on.
If this function is to be called on the same @pattern more than once, it's more efficient to compile the pattern once with g_regex_new() and then use g_regex_match().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: compile_options
parameter.parameter_description: compile options for the regular expression, or 0

function.return: %TRUE if the string matched, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_regex_new
function.description:
Compiles the regular expression to an internal form, and does the initial setup of the #GRegex structure.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: compile_options
parameter.parameter_description: compile options for the regular expression, or 0

parameter.name: match_options
parameter.parameter_description: match options for the regular expression, or 0

function.return: a #GRegex structure or %NULL if an error occurred. Call g_regex_unref() when you are done with it

function.name: g_regex_ref
function.description:
Increases reference count of @regex by 1.
Since: 2.14
function.return: @regex

function.name: g_regex_replace
function.description:
Replaces all occurrences of the pattern in @regex with the replacement text. Backreferences of the form `\number` or `\g<number>` in the replacement text are interpolated by the number-th captured subexpression of the match, `\g<name>` refers to the captured subexpression with the given name. `\0` refers to the complete match, but `\0` followed by a number is the octal representation of a character. To include a literal `\` in the replacement, write `\\\\`.
There are also escapes that changes the case of the following text:
- \l: Convert to lower case the next character - \u: Convert to upper case the next character - \L: Convert to lower case till \E - \U: Convert to upper case till \E - \E: End case modification
If you do not need to use backreferences use g_regex_replace_literal().
The @replacement string must be UTF-8 encoded even if %G_REGEX_RAW was passed to g_regex_new(). If you want to use not UTF-8 encoded strings you can use g_regex_replace_literal().
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting %G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to perform matches against

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match, in bytes

parameter.name: replacement
parameter.parameter_description: text to replace each match with

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the replacements

function.name: g_regex_replace_eval

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match, in bytes

parameter.name: eval
parameter.parameter_description: a function to call for each match

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the function

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the replacements

function.name: g_regex_replace_literal
function.description:
Replaces all occurrences of the pattern in @regex with the replacement text. @replacement is replaced literally, to include backreferences use g_regex_replace().
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting %G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to perform matches against

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match, in bytes

parameter.name: replacement
parameter.parameter_description: text to replace each match with

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore errors

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the replacements

function.name: g_regex_split
function.description:
Breaks the string on the pattern, and returns an array of the tokens. If the pattern contains capturing parentheses, then the text for each of the substrings will also be returned. If the pattern does not match anywhere in the string, then the whole string is returned as the first token.
As a special case, the result of splitting the empty string "" is an empty vector, not a vector containing a single string. The reason for this special case is that being able to represent an empty vector is typically more useful than consistent handling of empty elements. If you do need to represent empty elements, you'll need to check for the empty string before calling this function.
A pattern that can match empty strings splits @string into separate characters wherever it matches the empty string between characters. For example splitting "ab c" using as a separator "\s*", you will get "a", "b" and "c".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to split with the pattern

function.return: a %NULL-terminated gchar ** array. Free it using g_strfreev()

function.name: g_regex_split_full
function.description:
Breaks the string on the pattern, and returns an array of the tokens. If the pattern contains capturing parentheses, then the text for each of the substrings will also be returned. If the pattern does not match anywhere in the string, then the whole string is returned as the first token.
As a special case, the result of splitting the empty string "" is an empty vector, not a vector containing a single string. The reason for this special case is that being able to represent an empty vector is typically more useful than consistent handling of empty elements. If you do need to represent empty elements, you'll need to check for the empty string before calling this function.
A pattern that can match empty strings splits @string into separate characters wherever it matches the empty string between characters. For example splitting "ab c" using as a separator "\s*", you will get "a", "b" and "c".
Setting @start_position differs from just passing over a shortened string and setting %G_REGEX_MATCH_NOTBOL in the case of a pattern that begins with any kind of lookbehind assertion, such as "\b".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to split with the pattern

parameter.name: string_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @string, in bytes, or -1 if @string is nul-terminated

parameter.name: start_position
parameter.parameter_description: starting index of the string to match, in bytes

parameter.name: max_tokens
parameter.parameter_description: the maximum number of tokens to split @string into. If this is less than 1, the string is split completely

function.return: a %NULL-terminated gchar ** array. Free it using g_strfreev()

function.name: g_regex_split_simple
function.description:
Breaks the string on the pattern, and returns an array of the tokens. If the pattern contains capturing parentheses, then the text for each of the substrings will also be returned. If the pattern does not match anywhere in the string, then the whole string is returned as the first token.
This function is equivalent to g_regex_split() but it does not require to compile the pattern with g_regex_new(), avoiding some lines of code when you need just to do a split without extracting substrings, capture counts, and so on.
If this function is to be called on the same @pattern more than once, it's more efficient to compile the pattern once with g_regex_new() and then use g_regex_split().
As a special case, the result of splitting the empty string "" is an empty vector, not a vector containing a single string. The reason for this special case is that being able to represent an empty vector is typically more useful than consistent handling of empty elements. If you do need to represent empty elements, you'll need to check for the empty string before calling this function.
A pattern that can match empty strings splits @string into separate characters wherever it matches the empty string between characters. For example splitting "ab c" using as a separator "\s*", you will get "a", "b" and "c".
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: the string to scan for matches

parameter.name: compile_options
parameter.parameter_description: compile options for the regular expression, or 0

function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of strings. Free it using g_strfreev()

function.name: g_regex_unref
function.description:
Decreases reference count of @regex by 1. When reference count drops to zero, it frees all the memory associated with the regex structure.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_relation_count
function.description:
Returns the number of tuples in a #GRelation that have the given value in the given field.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field of each record to match.

function.return: the number of matches.

function.name: g_relation_delete
function.description:
Deletes any records from a #GRelation that have the given key value in the given field.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field of each record to match.

function.return: the number of records deleted.

function.name: g_relation_destroy
function.description:
Destroys the #GRelation, freeing all memory allocated. However, it does not free memory allocated for the tuple data, so you should free that first if appropriate.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

function.name: g_relation_exists
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if a record with the given values exists in a #GRelation. Note that the values are compared directly, so that, for example, two copies of the same string will not match.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the fields of the record to compare. The number must match the number of fields in the #GRelation.

function.return: %TRUE if a record matches.

function.name: g_relation_index
function.description:
Creates an index on the given field. Note that this must be called before any records are added to the #GRelation.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field to index, counting from 0.

parameter.name: hash_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to produce a hash value from the field data.

parameter.name: key_equal_func
parameter.parameter_description: a function to compare two values of the given field.

function.name: g_relation_insert
function.description:
Inserts a record into a #GRelation.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the fields of the record to add. These must match the number of fields in the #GRelation, and of type #gpointer or #gconstpointer.

function.name: g_relation_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GRelation with the given number of fields. Note that currently the number of fields must be 2.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API
function.return: a new #GRelation.

function.name: g_relation_print
function.description:
Outputs information about all records in a #GRelation, as well as the indexes. It is for debugging.
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

function.name: g_relation_select
function.description:
Returns all of the tuples which have the given key in the given field. Use g_tuples_index() to access the returned records. The returned records should be freed with g_tuples_destroy().
Deprecated: 2.26: Rarely used API

parameter.name: field
parameter.parameter_description: the field of each record to match.

function.return: the records (tuples) that matched.

function.name: g_reload_user_special_dirs_cache
function.description:
Resets the cache used for g_get_user_special_dir(), so that the latest on-disk version is used. Call this only if you just changed the data on disk yourself.
Due to thread safety issues this may cause leaking of strings that were previously returned from g_get_user_special_dir() that can't be freed. We ensure to only leak the data for the directories that actually changed value though.
Since: 2.22

function.name: g_remove
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX remove() function. The remove() function deletes a name from the filesystem.
See your C library manual for more details about how remove() works on your system. On Unix, remove() removes also directories, as it calls unlink() for files and rmdir() for directories. On Windows, although remove() in the C library only works for files, this function tries first remove() and then if that fails rmdir(), and thus works for both files and directories. Note however, that on Windows, it is in general not possible to remove a file that is open to some process, or mapped into memory.
If this function fails on Windows you can't infer too much from the errno value. rmdir() is tried regardless of what caused remove() to fail. Any errno value set by remove() will be overwritten by that set by rmdir().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

function.return: 0 if the file was successfully removed, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_rename
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX rename() function. The rename() function renames a file, moving it between directories if required.
See your C library manual for more details about how rename() works on your system. It is not possible in general on Windows to rename a file that is open to some process.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: oldfilename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

parameter.name: newfilename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: 0 if the renaming succeeded, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_renew
function.description: Reallocates the memory pointed to by @mem, so that it now has space for @n_structs elements of type @struct_type. It returns the new address of the memory, which may have been moved. Care is taken to avoid overflow when calculating the size of the allocated block.

parameter.name: struct_type
parameter.parameter_description: the type of the elements to allocate

parameter.name: n_structs
parameter.parameter_description: the number of elements to allocate

function.return: a pointer to the new allocated memory, cast to a pointer to @struct_type

function.name: g_return_if_fail
function.description:
Verifies that the expression @expr, usually representing a precondition, evaluates to %TRUE. If the function returns a value, use g_return_val_if_fail() instead.
If @expr evaluates to %FALSE, the current function should be considered to have undefined behaviour (a programmer error). The only correct solution to such an error is to change the module that is calling the current function, so that it avoids this incorrect call.
To make this undefined behaviour visible, if @expr evaluates to %FALSE, the result is usually that a critical message is logged and the current function returns.
If `G_DISABLE_CHECKS` is defined then the check is not performed. You should therefore not depend on any side effects of @expr.
To debug failure of a g_return_if_fail() check, run the code under a debugger with `G_DEBUG=fatal-criticals` or `G_DEBUG=fatal-warnings` defined in the environment (see [Running GLib Applications](running.html)):
|[ G_DEBUG=fatal-warnings gdb ./my-program ]|
Any unrelated failures can be skipped over in [gdb](https://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/) using the `continue` command.

function.name: g_return_if_fail_warning
function.description: Internal function used to print messages from the public [func@GLib.return_if_fail] and [func@GLib.return_val_if_fail] macros.

function.name: g_return_if_reached
function.description:
Logs a critical message and returns from the current function. This can only be used in functions which do not return a value.
See g_return_if_fail() for guidance on how to debug failure of this check.

function.name: g_return_val_if_fail
function.description:
Verifies that the expression @expr, usually representing a precondition, evaluates to %TRUE. If the function does not return a value, use g_return_if_fail() instead.
If @expr evaluates to %FALSE, the current function should be considered to have undefined behaviour (a programmer error). The only correct solution to such an error is to change the module that is calling the current function, so that it avoids this incorrect call.
To make this undefined behaviour visible, if @expr evaluates to %FALSE, the result is usually that a critical message is logged and @val is returned from the current function.
If `G_DISABLE_CHECKS` is defined then the check is not performed. You should therefore not depend on any side effects of @expr.
See g_return_if_fail() for guidance on how to debug failure of this check.

parameter.name: val
parameter.parameter_description: the value to return from the current function if the expression is not true

function.name: g_return_val_if_reached
function.description:
Logs a critical message and returns @val.
See g_return_if_fail() for guidance on how to debug failure of this check.

parameter.name: val
parameter.parameter_description: the value to return from the current function

function.name: g_rmdir
function.description:
A wrapper for the POSIX rmdir() function. The rmdir() function deletes a directory from the filesystem.
See your C library manual for more details about how rmdir() works on your system.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: a pathname in the GLib file name encoding (UTF-8 on Windows)

function.return: 0 if the directory was successfully removed, -1 if an error occurred

function.name: g_rw_lock_clear
function.description:
Frees the resources allocated to a lock with g_rw_lock_init().
This function should not be used with a #GRWLock that has been statically allocated.
Calling g_rw_lock_clear() when any thread holds the lock leads to undefined behaviour.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_rw_lock_init
g_rw_lock_reader_lock
function.description:
Obtain a read lock on @rw_lock. If another thread currently holds the write lock on @rw_lock, the current thread will block until the write lock was (held and) released. If another thread does not hold the write lock, but is waiting for it, it is implementation defined whether the reader or writer will block. Read locks can be taken recursively.
Calling g_rw_lock_reader_lock() while the current thread already owns a write lock leads to undefined behaviour. Read locks however can be taken recursively, in which case you need to make sure to call g_rw_lock_reader_unlock() the same amount of times.
It is implementation-defined how many read locks are allowed to be held on the same lock simultaneously. If the limit is hit, or if a deadlock is detected, a critical warning will be emitted.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_rw_lock_reader_locker_free
function.description:
Release a read lock on @locker's read-write lock. See g_rw_lock_reader_locker_new() for details.
No memory is freed, it is equivalent to a g_rw_lock_reader_unlock() call.
Since: 2.62

function.name: g_rw_lock_reader_locker_new
function.description:
Obtain a read lock on @rw_lock and return a new #GRWLockReaderLocker. Unlock with g_rw_lock_reader_locker_free(). Using g_rw_lock_reader_unlock() on @rw_lock while a #GRWLockReaderLocker exists can lead to undefined behaviour.
No allocation is performed, it is equivalent to a g_rw_lock_reader_lock() call.
This is intended to be used with g_autoptr(). For a code sample, see g_rw_lock_writer_locker_new().
Since: 2.62
function.return: a #GRWLockReaderLocker

function.name: g_rw_lock_reader_trylock
function.description:
Tries to obtain a read lock on @rw_lock and returns %TRUE if the read lock was successfully obtained. Otherwise it returns %FALSE.
Since: 2.32
function.return: %TRUE if @rw_lock could be locked

function.name: g_rw_lock_reader_unlock
function.description:
Release a read lock on @rw_lock.
Calling g_rw_lock_reader_unlock() on a lock that is not held by the current thread leads to undefined behaviour.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_rw_lock_writer_lock
function.description:
Obtain a write lock on @rw_lock. If another thread currently holds a read or write lock on @rw_lock, the current thread will block until all other threads have dropped their locks on @rw_lock.
Calling g_rw_lock_writer_lock() while the current thread already owns a read or write lock on @rw_lock leads to undefined behaviour.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_rw_lock_writer_locker_free
function.description:
Release a write lock on @locker's read-write lock. See g_rw_lock_writer_locker_new() for details.
No memory is freed, it is equivalent to a g_rw_lock_writer_unlock() call.
Since: 2.62

function.name: g_rw_lock_writer_locker_new
function.return: a #GRWLockWriterLocker

function.name: g_rw_lock_writer_trylock
function.description:
Tries to obtain a write lock on @rw_lock. If another thread currently holds a read or write lock on @rw_lock, it immediately returns %FALSE. Otherwise it locks @rw_lock and returns %TRUE.
Since: 2.32
function.return: %TRUE if @rw_lock could be locked

function.name: g_rw_lock_writer_unlock
function.description:
Release a write lock on @rw_lock.
Calling g_rw_lock_writer_unlock() on a lock that is not held by the current thread leads to undefined behaviour.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_scanner_add_symbol
function.description:
Adds a symbol to the default scope.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_scanner_scope_add_symbol() instead.

function.name: g_scanner_cur_line
function.description: Returns the current line in the input stream (counting from 1). This is the line of the last token parsed via g_scanner_get_next_token().
function.return: the current line

function.name: g_scanner_cur_position
function.description: Returns the current position in the current line (counting from 0). This is the position of the last token parsed via g_scanner_get_next_token().
function.return: the current position on the line

function.name: g_scanner_cur_token
function.description: Gets the current token type. This is simply the @token field in the #GScanner structure.
function.return: the current token type

function.name: g_scanner_cur_value
function.description: Gets the current token value. This is simply the @value field in the #GScanner structure.
function.return: the current token value

function.name: g_scanner_destroy
function.description: Frees all memory used by the #GScanner.

function.name: g_scanner_eof
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the scanner has reached the end of the file or text buffer.
function.return: %TRUE if the scanner has reached the end of the file or text buffer

function.name: g_scanner_error
function.description: Outputs an error message, via the #GScanner message handler.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the message format. See the printf() documentation

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to insert into the format string

function.name: g_scanner_foreach_symbol
function.description:
Calls a function for each symbol in the default scope.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_scanner_scope_foreach_symbol() instead.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call with each symbol

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: data to pass to the function

function.name: g_scanner_freeze_symbol_table
function.description:
There is no reason to use this macro, since it does nothing.
Deprecated: 2.2: This macro does nothing.

function.name: g_scanner_get_next_token
function.description: Parses the next token just like g_scanner_peek_next_token() and also removes it from the input stream. The token data is placed in the @token, @value, @line, and @position fields of the #GScanner structure.
function.return: the type of the token

function.name: g_scanner_input_file
function.description: Prepares to scan a file.

function.name: g_scanner_input_text
function.description: Prepares to scan a text buffer.

parameter.name: text_len
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the text buffer

function.name: g_scanner_lookup_symbol
function.description: Looks up a symbol in the current scope and return its value. If the symbol is not bound in the current scope, %NULL is returned.
function.return: the value of @symbol in the current scope, or %NULL if @symbol is not bound in the current scope

function.name: g_scanner_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GScanner.
The @config_templ structure specifies the initial settings of the scanner, which are copied into the #GScanner @config field. If you pass %NULL then the default settings are used.
function.return: the new #GScanner

function.name: g_scanner_peek_next_token
function.description:
Parses the next token, without removing it from the input stream. The token data is placed in the @next_token, @next_value, @next_line, and @next_position fields of the #GScanner structure.
Note that, while the token is not removed from the input stream (i.e. the next call to g_scanner_get_next_token() will return the same token), it will not be reevaluated. This can lead to surprising results when changing scope or the scanner configuration after peeking the next token. Getting the next token after switching the scope or configuration will return whatever was peeked before, regardless of any symbols that may have been added or removed in the new scope.
function.return: the type of the token

function.name: g_scanner_remove_symbol
function.description:
Removes a symbol from the default scope.
Deprecated: 2.2: Use g_scanner_scope_remove_symbol() instead.

function.name: g_scanner_scope_add_symbol
function.description: Adds a symbol to the given scope.

function.name: g_scanner_scope_foreach_symbol
function.description: Calls the given function for each of the symbol/value pairs in the given scope of the #GScanner. The function is passed the symbol and value of each pair, and the given @user_data parameter.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each symbol/value pair

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the function

function.name: g_scanner_scope_lookup_symbol
function.description: Looks up a symbol in a scope and return its value. If the symbol is not bound in the scope, %NULL is returned.
function.return: the value of @symbol in the given scope, or %NULL if @symbol is not bound in the given scope.

function.name: g_scanner_scope_remove_symbol
function.description: Removes a symbol from a scope.

function.name: g_scanner_set_scope
function.description: Sets the current scope.
function.return: the old scope id

function.name: g_scanner_sync_file_offset
function.description: Rewinds the filedescriptor to the current buffer position and blows the file read ahead buffer. This is useful for third party uses of the scanners filedescriptor, which hooks onto the current scanning position.

function.name: g_scanner_thaw_symbol_table
function.description:
There is no reason to use this macro, since it does nothing.
Deprecated: 2.2: This macro does nothing.

function.name: g_scanner_unexp_token
function.description: Outputs a message through the scanner's msg_handler, resulting from an unexpected token in the input stream. Note that you should not call g_scanner_peek_next_token() followed by g_scanner_unexp_token() without an intermediate call to g_scanner_get_next_token(), as g_scanner_unexp_token() evaluates the scanner's current token (not the peeked token) to construct part of the message.

parameter.name: identifier_spec
parameter.parameter_description: a string describing how the scanner's user refers to identifiers (%NULL defaults to "identifier"). This is used if @expected_token is %G_TOKEN_IDENTIFIER or %G_TOKEN_IDENTIFIER_NULL.

parameter.name: symbol_spec
parameter.parameter_description: a string describing how the scanner's user refers to symbols (%NULL defaults to "symbol"). This is used if @expected_token is %G_TOKEN_SYMBOL or any token value greater than %G_TOKEN_LAST.

parameter.name: symbol_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the symbol, if the scanner's current token is a symbol.

parameter.name: message
parameter.parameter_description: a message string to output at the end of the warning/error, or %NULL.

parameter.name: is_error
parameter.parameter_description: if %TRUE it is output as an error. If %FALSE it is output as a warning.

function.name: g_scanner_warn
function.description: Outputs a warning message, via the #GScanner message handler.

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the message format. See the printf() documentation

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: the parameters to insert into the format string

function.name: g_sequence_append
function.description:
Adds a new item to the end of @seq.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new item

function.return: an iterator pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_foreach
function.description:
Calls @func for each item in the sequence passing @user_data to the function. @func must not modify the sequence itself.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the function to call for each item in @seq

function.name: g_sequence_foreach_range
function.description:
Calls @func for each item in the range (@begin, @end) passing @user_data to the function. @func must not modify the sequence itself.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_free
function.description:
Frees the memory allocated for @seq. If @seq has a data destroy function associated with it, that function is called on all items in @seq.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_get
function.description:
Returns the data that @iter points to.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the data that @iter points to

function.name: g_sequence_get_begin_iter
function.description:
Returns the begin iterator for @seq.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the begin iterator for @seq.

function.name: g_sequence_get_end_iter
function.description:
Returns the end iterator for @seg
Since: 2.14
function.return: the end iterator for @seq

function.name: g_sequence_get_iter_at_pos
function.description:
Returns the iterator at position @pos. If @pos is negative or larger than the number of items in @seq, the end iterator is returned.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: pos
parameter.parameter_description: a position in @seq, or -1 for the end

function.return: The #GSequenceIter at position @pos

function.name: g_sequence_get_length
function.description:
Returns the positive length (>= 0) of @seq. Note that this method is O(h) where `h' is the height of the tree. It is thus more efficient to use g_sequence_is_empty() when comparing the length to zero.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the length of @seq

function.name: g_sequence_insert_before
function.description:
Inserts a new item just before the item pointed to by @iter.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new item

function.return: an iterator pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_insert_sorted
function.description:
Inserts @data into @seq using @cmp_func to determine the new position. The sequence must already be sorted according to @cmp_func; otherwise the new position of @data is undefined.
@cmp_func is called with two items of the @seq, and @cmp_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.
Note that when adding a large amount of data to a #GSequence, it is more efficient to do unsorted insertions and then call g_sequence_sort() or g_sequence_sort_iter().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare items in the sequence

function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the new item.

function.name: g_sequence_insert_sorted_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_insert_sorted(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
@iter_cmp is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.
Note that when adding a large amount of data to a #GSequence, it is more efficient to do unsorted insertions and then call g_sequence_sort() or g_sequence_sort_iter().
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare iterators in the sequence

function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_is_empty
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the sequence contains zero items.
This function is functionally identical to checking the result of g_sequence_get_length() being equal to zero. However this function is implemented in O(1) running time.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE if the sequence is empty, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: g_sequence_iter_compare
function.description:
Returns a negative number if @a comes before @b, 0 if they are equal, and a positive number if @a comes after @b.
The @a and @b iterators must point into the same sequence.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a negative number if @a comes before @b, 0 if they are equal, and a positive number if @a comes after @b

function.name: g_sequence_iter_get_position
function.description:
Returns the position of @iter
Since: 2.14
function.return: the position of @iter

function.name: g_sequence_iter_get_sequence
function.description:
Returns the #GSequence that @iter points into.
Since: 2.14
function.return: the #GSequence that @iter points into

function.name: g_sequence_iter_is_begin
function.description:
Returns whether @iter is the begin iterator
Since: 2.14
function.return: whether @iter is the begin iterator

function.name: g_sequence_iter_is_end
function.description:
Returns whether @iter is the end iterator
Since: 2.14
function.return: Whether @iter is the end iterator

function.name: g_sequence_iter_move
function.description:
Returns the #GSequenceIter which is @delta positions away from @iter. If @iter is closer than -@delta positions to the beginning of the sequence, the begin iterator is returned. If @iter is closer than @delta positions to the end of the sequence, the end iterator is returned.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: delta
parameter.parameter_description: A positive or negative number indicating how many positions away from @iter the returned #GSequenceIter will be

function.return: a #GSequenceIter which is @delta positions away from @iter

function.name: g_sequence_iter_next
function.description:
Returns an iterator pointing to the next position after @iter. If @iter is the end iterator, the end iterator is returned.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the next position after @iter

function.name: g_sequence_iter_prev
function.description:
Returns an iterator pointing to the previous position before @iter. If @iter is the begin iterator, the begin iterator is returned.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the previous position before @iter

function.name: g_sequence_lookup
function.description:
Returns an iterator pointing to the position of the first item found equal to @data according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data. If more than one item is equal, it is not guaranteed that it is the first which is returned. In that case, you can use g_sequence_iter_next() and g_sequence_iter_prev() to get others.
@cmp_func is called with two items of the @seq, and @cmp_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.
This function will fail if the data contained in the sequence is unsorted.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare items in the sequence

function.name: g_sequence_lookup_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_lookup(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
@iter_cmp is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.
This function will fail if the data contained in the sequence is unsorted.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare iterators in the sequence

function.return: an #GSequenceIter pointing to the position of the first item found equal to @data according to @iter_cmp and @cmp_data, or %NULL if no such item exists

function.name: g_sequence_move
function.description:
Moves the item pointed to by @src to the position indicated by @dest. After calling this function @dest will point to the position immediately after @src. It is allowed for @src and @dest to point into different sequences.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: src
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the item to move

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the position to which the item is moved

function.name: g_sequence_move_range
function.description:
Inserts the (@begin, @end) range at the destination pointed to by @dest. The @begin and @end iters must point into the same sequence. It is allowed for @dest to point to a different sequence than the one pointed into by @begin and @end.
If @dest is %NULL, the range indicated by @begin and @end is removed from the sequence. If @dest points to a place within the (@begin, @end) range, the range does not move.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_new
function.description:
Creates a new GSequence. The @data_destroy function, if non-%NULL will be called on all items when the sequence is destroyed and on items that are removed from the sequence.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a new #GSequence

function.name: g_sequence_prepend
function.description:
Adds a new item to the front of @seq
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: the data for the new item

function.return: an iterator pointing to the new item

function.name: g_sequence_range_get_midpoint
function.description:
Finds an iterator somewhere in the range (@begin, @end). This iterator will be close to the middle of the range, but is not guaranteed to be exactly in the middle.
The @begin and @end iterators must both point to the same sequence and @begin must come before or be equal to @end in the sequence.
Since: 2.14
function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing somewhere in the (@begin, @end) range

function.name: g_sequence_remove
function.description:
Removes the item pointed to by @iter. It is an error to pass the end iterator to this function.
If the sequence has a data destroy function associated with it, this function is called on the data for the removed item.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_remove_range
function.description:
Removes all items in the (@begin, @end) range.
If the sequence has a data destroy function associated with it, this function is called on the data for the removed items.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_search
function.description:
Returns an iterator pointing to the position where @data would be inserted according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data.
@cmp_func is called with two items of the @seq, and @cmp_data. It should return 0 if the items are equal, a negative value if the first item comes before the second, and a positive value if the second item comes before the first.
If you are simply searching for an existing element of the sequence, consider using g_sequence_lookup().
This function will fail if the data contained in the sequence is unsorted.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare items in the sequence

function.return: an #GSequenceIter pointing to the position where @data would have been inserted according to @cmp_func and @cmp_data

function.name: g_sequence_search_iter
function.description:
Like g_sequence_search(), but uses a #GSequenceIterCompareFunc instead of a #GCompareDataFunc as the compare function.
@iter_cmp is called with two iterators pointing into @seq. It should return 0 if the iterators are equal, a negative value if the first iterator comes before the second, and a positive value if the second iterator comes before the first.
If you are simply searching for an existing element of the sequence, consider using g_sequence_lookup_iter().
This function will fail if the data contained in the sequence is unsorted.
Since: 2.14

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare iterators in the sequence

function.return: a #GSequenceIter pointing to the position in @seq where @data would have been inserted according to @iter_cmp and @cmp_data

function.name: g_sequence_set
function.description:
Changes the data for the item pointed to by @iter to be @data. If the sequence has a data destroy function associated with it, that function is called on the existing data that @iter pointed to.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_sequence_sort

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to sort the sequence

function.name: g_sequence_sort_changed

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare items in the sequence

function.name: g_sequence_sort_changed_iter

parameter.name: iter_cmp
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare iterators in the sequence

function.name: g_sequence_sort_iter

parameter.name: cmp_func
parameter.parameter_description: the function used to compare iterators in the sequence

function.name: g_sequence_swap
function.description:
Swaps the items pointed to by @a and @b. It is allowed for @a and @b to point into difference sequences.
Since: 2.14

function.name: g_set_application_name
function.description:
Sets a human-readable name for the application. This name should be localized if possible, and is intended for display to the user. Contrast with g_set_prgname(), which sets a non-localized name. g_set_prgname() will be called automatically by gtk_init(), but g_set_application_name() will not.
Note that for thread safety reasons, this function can only be called once.
The application name will be used in contexts such as error messages, or when displaying an application's name in the task list.
Since: 2.2

function.name: g_set_error
function.description: Does nothing if @err is %NULL; if @err is non-%NULL, then `*err` must be %NULL. A new #GError is created and assigned to `*err`.

function.name: g_set_error_literal
function.description:
Does nothing if @err is %NULL; if @err is non-%NULL, then `*err` must be %NULL. A new #GError is created and assigned to `*err`. Unlike g_set_error(), @message is not a printf()-style format string. Use this function if @message contains text you don't have control over, that could include printf() escape sequences.
Since: 2.18

function.name: g_set_object

parameter.name: new_object
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the new #GObject to assign to @object_ptr, or %NULL to clear the pointer

function.return: %TRUE if the value of @object_ptr changed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_set_prgname
function.description:
Sets the name of the program. This name should not be localized, in contrast to g_set_application_name().
If you are using #GApplication the program name is set in g_application_run(). In case of GDK or GTK it is set in gdk_init(), which is called by gtk_init() and the #GtkApplication::startup handler. By default, the program name is found by taking the last component of @argv[0].
Since GLib 2.72, this function can be called multiple times and is fully thread safe. Prior to GLib 2.72, this function could only be called once per process.
See the [GTK documentation](https://docs.gtk.org/gtk4/migrating-3to4.html#set-a-proper-application-id) for requirements on integrating g_set_prgname() with GTK applications.

function.name: g_set_prgname_once
function.description: If g_get_prgname() is not set, this is the same as setting the name via g_set_prgname() and %TRUE is returned. Otherwise, does nothing and returns %FALSE. This is thread-safe.
function.return: whether g_prgname was initialized by the call.

function.name: g_set_print_handler
function.description:
Sets the print handler to @func, or resets it to the default GLib handler if `NULL`.
Any messages passed to [func@GLib.print] will be output via the new handler. The default handler outputs the encoded message to `stdout`. By providing your own handler you can redirect the output, to a GTK widget or a log file for example.
Since 2.76 this functions always returns a valid [type@GLib.PrintFunc], and never returns `NULL`. If no custom print handler was set, it will return the GLib default print handler and that can be re-used to decorate its output and/or to write to `stderr` in all platforms. Before GLib 2.76, this was `NULL`.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: the new print handler or `NULL` to reset to the default

function.return: the old print handler

function.name: g_set_printerr_handler
function.description:
Sets the handler for printing error messages to @func, or resets it to the default GLib handler if `NULL`.
Any messages passed to [func@GLib.printerr] will be output via the new handler. The default handler outputs the encoded message to `stderr`. By providing your own handler you can redirect the output, to a GTK widget or a log file for example.
Since 2.76 this functions always returns a valid [type@GLib.PrintFunc], and never returns `NULL`. If no custom error print handler was set, it will return the GLib default error print handler and that can be re-used to decorate its output and/or to write to `stderr` in all platforms. Before GLib 2.76, this was `NULL`.

parameter.name: func
parameter.parameter_description: he new error message handler or `NULL` to reset to the default

function.return: the old error message handler

function.name: g_set_str

parameter.name: str_pointer
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to either a string or `NULL`

function.return: true if the value of @str_pointer changed, false otherwise

function.name: g_set_weak_pointer

parameter.name: weak_pointer_location
parameter.parameter_description: the memory address of a pointer

parameter.name: new_object
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the new #GObject to assign to it, or %NULL to clear the pointer

function.return: %TRUE if the value of @weak_pointer_location changed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_setenv
function.description:
Sets an environment variable. On UNIX, both the variable's name and value can be arbitrary byte strings, except that the variable's name cannot contain '='. On Windows, they should be in UTF-8.
Note that on some systems, when variables are overwritten, the memory used for the previous variables and its value isn't reclaimed.
You should be mindful of the fact that environment variable handling in UNIX is not thread-safe, and your program may crash if one thread calls g_setenv() while another thread is calling getenv(). (And note that many functions, such as gettext(), call getenv() internally.) This function is only safe to use at the very start of your program, before creating any other threads (or creating objects that create worker threads of their own).
If you need to set up the environment for a child process, you can use g_get_environ() to get an environment array, modify that with g_environ_setenv() and g_environ_unsetenv(), and then pass that array directly to execvpe(), g_spawn_async(), or the like.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: variable
parameter.parameter_description: the environment variable to set, must not contain '='.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the value for to set the variable to.

parameter.name: overwrite
parameter.parameter_description: whether to change the variable if it already exists.

function.return: %FALSE if the environment variable couldn't be set.

function.name: g_shell_parse_argv
function.description:
Parses a command line into an argument vector, in much the same way the shell would, but without many of the expansions the shell would perform (variable expansion, globs, operators, filename expansion, etc. are not supported).
The results are defined to be the same as those you would get from a UNIX98 `/bin/sh`, as long as the input contains none of the unsupported shell expansions. If the input does contain such expansions, they are passed through literally.
Possible errors are those from the %G_SHELL_ERROR domain.
In particular, if @command_line is an empty string (or a string containing only whitespace), %G_SHELL_ERROR_EMPTY_STRING will be returned. It’s guaranteed that @argvp will be a non-empty array if this function returns successfully.
Free the returned vector with g_strfreev().

parameter.name: argcp
parameter.parameter_description: return location for number of args

parameter.name: argvp
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of args

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE if error set

function.name: g_shell_quote
function.description:
Quotes a string so that the shell (/bin/sh) will interpret the quoted string to mean @unquoted_string.
If you pass a filename to the shell, for example, you should first quote it with this function.
The return value must be freed with g_free().
The quoting style used is undefined (single or double quotes may be used).
function.return: quoted string

function.name: g_shell_unquote
function.description:
Unquotes a string as the shell (/bin/sh) would.
This function only handles quotes; if a string contains file globs, arithmetic operators, variables, backticks, redirections, or other special-to-the-shell features, the result will be different from the result a real shell would produce (the variables, backticks, etc. will be passed through literally instead of being expanded).
This function is guaranteed to succeed if applied to the result of g_shell_quote(). If it fails, it returns %NULL and sets the error.
The @quoted_string need not actually contain quoted or escaped text; g_shell_unquote() simply goes through the string and unquotes/unescapes anything that the shell would. Both single and double quotes are handled, as are escapes including escaped newlines.
The return value must be freed with g_free().
Possible errors are in the %G_SHELL_ERROR domain.
Shell quoting rules are a bit strange. Single quotes preserve the literal string exactly. escape sequences are not allowed; not even `\'` - if you want a `'` in the quoted text, you have to do something like `'foo'\''bar'`. Double quotes allow `$`, ```, `"`, `\`, and newline to be escaped with backslash. Otherwise double quotes preserve things literally.
function.return: an unquoted string

function.name: g_signal_accumulator_first_wins
function.description:
A predefined #GSignalAccumulator for signals intended to be used as a hook for application code to provide a particular value. Usually only one such value is desired and multiple handlers for the same signal don't make much sense (except for the case of the default handler defined in the class structure, in which case you will usually want the signal connection to override the class handler).
This accumulator will use the return value from the first signal handler that is run as the return value for the signal and not run any further handlers (ie: the first handler "wins").
Since: 2.28
function.return: standard #GSignalAccumulator result

function.name: g_signal_accumulator_true_handled
function.description:
A predefined #GSignalAccumulator for signals that return a boolean values. The behavior that this accumulator gives is that a return of %TRUE stops the signal emission: no further callbacks will be invoked, while a return of %FALSE allows the emission to continue. The idea here is that a %TRUE return indicates that the callback handled the signal, and no further handling is needed.
Since: 2.4
function.return: standard #GSignalAccumulator result

function.name: g_signal_add_emission_hook
function.description: Adds an emission hook for a signal, which will get called for any emission of that signal, independent of the instance. This is possible only for signals which don't have %G_SIGNAL_NO_HOOKS flag set.

parameter.name: signal_id
parameter.parameter_description: the signal identifier, as returned by g_signal_lookup().

parameter.name: detail
parameter.parameter_description: the detail on which to call the hook.

function.return: the hook id, for later use with g_signal_remove_emission_hook().

function.name: g_signal_chain_from_overridden
function.description: Calls the original class closure of a signal. This function should only be called from an overridden class closure; see g_signal_override_class_closure() and g_signal_override_class_handler().

parameter.name: instance_and_params
parameter.parameter_description: the argument list of the signal emission. The first element in the array is a #GValue for the instance the signal is being emitted on. The rest are any arguments to be passed to the signal.

function.name: g_signal_chain_from_overridden_handler
function.description:
Calls the original class closure of a signal. This function should only be called from an overridden class closure; see g_signal_override_class_closure() and g_signal_override_class_handler().
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: instance
parameter.parameter_description: the instance the signal is being emitted on.

parameter.name: Varargs
parameter.parameter_description: parameters to be passed to the parent class closure, followed by a location for the return value. If the return type of the signal is %G_TYPE_NONE, the return value location can be omitted.

function.name: g_signal_connect
function.description:
Connects a [type@GObject.Callback] function to a signal for a particular object.
The handler will be called synchronously, before the default handler of the signal. [func@GObject.signal_emit] will not return control until all handlers are called.
See [memory management of signal handlers](signals.html#memory-management-of-signal-handlers) for details on how to handle the return value and memory management of @data.
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the ‘detail’ string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.
function.return: the handler ID, of type `gulong` (always greater than 0)

function.name: g_signal_connect_after
function.description:
Connects a #GCallback function to a signal for a particular object.
The handler will be called synchronously, after the default handler of the signal.
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the ‘detail’ string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.
function.return: the handler ID, of type `gulong` (always greater than 0)

function.name: g_signal_connect_closure
function.description:
Connects a closure to a signal for a particular object.
If @closure is a floating reference (see g_closure_sink()), this function takes ownership of @closure.
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the ‘detail’ string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.

parameter.name: after
parameter.parameter_description: whether the handler should be called before or after the default handler of the signal.

function.return: the handler ID (always greater than 0)

function.name: g_signal_connect_closure_by_id
function.description:
Connects a closure to a signal for a particular object.
If @closure is a floating reference (see g_closure_sink()), this function takes ownership of @closure.
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the ‘detail’ string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.

parameter.name: after
parameter.parameter_description: whether the handler should be called before or after the default handler of the signal.

function.return: the handler ID (always greater than 0)

function.name: g_signal_connect_data
function.description:
Connects a #GCallback function to a signal for a particular object. Similar to g_signal_connect(), but allows to provide a #GClosureNotify for the data which will be called when the signal handler is disconnected and no longer used. Specify @connect_flags if you need `..._after()` or `..._swapped()` variants of this function.
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the ‘detail’ string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.
function.return: the handler ID (always greater than 0)

function.name: g_signal_connect_object
function.description:
This is similar to g_signal_connect_data(), but uses a closure which ensures that the @gobject stays alive during the call to @c_handler by temporarily adding a reference count to @gobject.
When the @gobject is destroyed the signal handler will be automatically disconnected. Note that this is not currently threadsafe (ie: emitting a signal while @gobject is being destroyed in another thread is not safe).
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the "detail" string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.

parameter.name: gobject
parameter.parameter_description: the object to pass as data to @c_handler.

function.return: the handler id.

function.name: g_signal_connect_swapped
function.description:
Connects a #GCallback function to a signal for a particular object.
The instance on which the signal is emitted and @data will be swapped when calling the handler. This is useful when calling pre-existing functions to operate purely on the @data, rather than the @instance: swapping the parameters avoids the need to write a wrapper function.
For example, this allows the shorter code: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_signal_connect_swapped (button, "clicked", (GCallback) gtk_widget_hide, other_widget); ]|
Rather than the cumbersome: |[<!-- language="C" --> static void button_clicked_cb (GtkButton *button, GtkWidget *other_widget) { gtk_widget_hide (other_widget); }
...
g_signal_connect (button, "clicked", (GCallback) button_clicked_cb, other_widget); ]|
This function cannot fail. If the given signal name doesn’t exist, a critical warning is emitted. No validation is performed on the ‘detail’ string when specified in @detailed_signal, other than a non-empty check.
Refer to the [signals documentation](signals.html) for more details.
function.return: the handler ID, of type `gulong` (always greater than 0)

function.name: g_signal_emit
function.description:
Emits a signal. Signal emission is done synchronously. The method will only return control after all handlers are called or signal emission was stopped.
